p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
PARLIAMENTARY OFFICE HOLDERS
Speaker's Panel

The SPEAKER (10:01): Pursuant to standing order 17, I lay on the table my warrant nominating the honourable members for O'Connor and Fisher to be members of the Speaker's panel to assist the chair when requested to do so by the Speaker or the Deputy Speaker.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:01): I present the second report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament. I also present a corrigendum to report No. 1 of 29 July 2019.
PETITIONS
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:01): I present the following 62 petitions:
Mining

This petition of students from St Aloysius' College, Milsons Point NSW, draws to the attention of the House that: The Adani Coal Mine Project proposal in the Galilee Basin (Queensland) poses extremely damaging environmental impacts if the project goes ahead. Carbon Dioxide emissions from coal produced at this plant are expected to be approximately 200 million tonnes in its production, with a further 130 million tonnes of Carbon Dioxide emissions yearly, associated with burning the coal. Pollution from burning coal is the largest contributor to global greenhouse gas emissions. Further, the mine plans to remove up to 270 billion litres of water over its lifetime, draining rivers, basins, and springs, in a currently drought stricken landscape. This project will also ignore the indigenous rights of the Wangan and Jagalingou people, who are inextricably linked to the lands, waters, and burial sites in the area, and maintain a continuing connection to the landscape. Your petitioners therefore request the House to: Revoke the approval given under the Environmental Protection Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 in October 2015 to mine on this land, and prevent the Adani Corporation from having exploration permits for coal. We also ask that the prospect, geographical surveying, drilling, sampling, and testing of this land be prevented by means of blocking the Adani corporation from receiving government funding, or tax breaks, to build infrastructure surrounding the mine, and begin the operation of the mine.
from 481 citizens (Petition No. PN0413)
Mining

This petition of 'certain citizens of Adelaide' Draws the attention of the House: The mining company Adani is about to build a mine on the Carmichael site in Queensland. The construction of this mine would ignore Indigenous rights and would have catastrophic consequences such as releasing a massive amount of greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, destroying the natural habitats of unique native animals and polluting the Carmichael river.
We therefore ask the House to: Stop Adani from building a mine in Queensland or anywhere in Australia.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. PN0414)
Australia Post

This petition of the residents of lllawong and Alfords Point in NSW draws to the attention of the House: The request of the community to have a post office outlet reinstated in the lllawong I Alfords Point area. There were over 10,500 people residing in the area at the time of the 2011 census. 13% of these residents are aged over 70. This means that there is a significant portion of the population who are less likely to be able to easily travel far from their residence. The area has been without a post office outlet since the licensee closed and we understand that person still holds the licence. The closest Australia Post outlet is located in Menai Marketplace, just over 5 km away.

We therefore ask the House to require Australia Post to offer a licence for post office outlet services to a local business within the lllawong and Alfords Point area as a matter of urgency. The lack of a local Australia Post outlet is having a detrimental effect on local residents and businesses.
from 289 citizens (Petition No. PN0415)
Asylum Seekers

This petition of citizens of Australia and other countries draws to the attention of the, House the ongoing distress of more than 900 asylum seekers who remain in Australia's offshore detention system. Australia continues to pay Papua New Guinea and Nauru - at an annual cost of half a million dollars per person - to house asylum seekers in conditions that have been plagued over years by revelations of physical violence - including murder - sexual abuse of women and children, allegations of torture by guards, medical neglect leading to death, and catastrophic rates of mental health decline, self-harm, and suicide attempts. Despite recent hard-won improvements to medical protocols, resettlement processing, including the limited US resettlement deal, continues to be dysfunctional, and a stop needs to be brought at last to this inhuman treatment of innocent people.

We therefore ask the House: - to bring an end to the disgrace by promptly resettling the asylum seekers in safe countries, including Australia, and - to implement a 'regional solution' with Indonesia and Malaysia which would humanely address the regional asylum seeker situation while circumventing the need for unsafe boat journeys to Australia
from 214 citizens (Petition No. PN0419)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

This petition by the citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that legislative changes are required to eliminate discrimination of older people with a disability. Older people are unable to access the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) after the age of 65. The maximum aged care Government subsidy of $49,000 per annum is insufficient for people who have extensive care needs, such as people who have quadriplegia. Regardless of age, people over the age of 65 with a disability should be entitled to access NDIS benefits to support them in receiving the care they require.
We therefore ask the House to: Change the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 to enable people over the age of 65 with a disability to access NDIS benefits.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. PN0420)
Falun Gong

TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES ASSEMBLED IN PARLIAMENT This petition of certain citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Falun Gong is a peaceful meditation practice based on the principles of Truthfulness, Compassion and Tolerance. Falun Gong practitioners in China have been subjected to the most brutal and relentless persecution by the Chinese Communist regime since July 1999. According to investigative reports published by human rights lawyer David Matas and former Canadian Secretary of State for the Asia Pacific David Kilgour, a large number of imprisoned Falun Gong practitioners have been subjected to forced organ harvesting for Chinas transplant market and lost their lives ( www.organharvestinvestigation.net ).
We therefore ask the House to request the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister to openly and forthrightly call for an immediate end to the persecution of Falun Gong in China.
from 2777 citizens (Petition No. PN0421)
Aged Care

This petition of Churchill and district community members and certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House to our support for the continuation of aged care services at Hazelwood House Churchill.
We therefore ask the House to not allow aged care places to be reallocated away from Churchill without community consent.
from 678 citizens (Petition No. PN0423)
Climate Change

The latest IPCC report (from the world's top climate scientists) says the world needs to achieve net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 to stand a chance of limiting global warming to 1.5 deg C. Without suitable action we are risking the futures of our children and grandchildren. They will face increasing 50 deg heat-waves, floods, storms, bush-fires and famine.

The world's largest emitters are the USA and China. We need them to adopt the net zero emissions policy. But they will not listen to Australia while Australians are the WORST GREENHOUSE GAS POLLUTERS IN THE OECD. So first we need to put our own house in order.

Individuals can only do so much. We need hundreds of small changes made to the way we live - the way we produce electricity, the way we transport ourselves and our goods, the way we build and manufacture, the way we farm and so on. These small changes do not need to harm our quality of life - but doing nothing will. We need our government to adopt a clear climate target which will drive policy action in all sectors of the economy. The present targets are not enough.
The State Governments of NSW and of Victoria have adopted aspirational targets of zero net greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
We therefore ask the House to adopt a national policy of net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
from 47 citizens (Petition No. EN0910)
Brunei: Human Rights

The Southeast Asian country of Brunei has declared homosexuality to be a crime punishable by stoning to death. Such a law is a barbaric violation of universal human rights. As a regional power of this corner of Asia, Australia must immediately issue a diplomatic notice of its disapproval of the action and ultimately cut off all relations if Brunei refuses to change course. Australia cannot allow its LGBT citizens be in danger of death, should they travel to the country without awareness of the law.

We therefore ask the House to issue a diplomatic notice to Brunei, and if the new law is not repealed, withdraw all diplomatic staff and issue travel bans on all citizens of Brunei, since they cannot secure the safety of Australian travelers there.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN0911)
Family Reunion Visas

Separation from family love and support is one of the most difficult factors in the settlement experience for refugees. Successful resettlement depends on becoming part of a social network, starting with the foundation provided by extended family.
Currently the Australian government is separating families held in detention centres and making it difficult for families resettling in Australia to reunite with their extended families. For example:
*some refugee visa holders are excluded from applying for family reunion;
*there is a substantial backlog of outstanding applications under the Special Humanitarian Program (SHP). In some cases delays in family reunion are expected to exceed 20 years;
*some refugees can sponsor family members through the family stream of the regular Migration Program, however visa application charges apply and there are significant delays in processing times; and
*those visa classes given the lowest processing priority are unlikely to ever be reunited with their families.

The Refugee Council of Australia recommends absorbing SHP split-families into a new, dedicated Humanitarian allocation of family visas in the General Migration Programme with lower or waived fees and need-based concessions.

Other recommendations are broadening the definition of immediate family, allocating more places in the SHP for family reunion and allowing unaccompanied minors who are refugees to propose family members.
We therefore ask the House to promote successful refugee settlement outcomes by supporting refugee family reunification in line with recommendations made by the Refugee Council of Australia.
from 61 citizens (Petition No. EN0914)
Disability Support Pension

People with permanent chronic illnesses are currently being placed on Newstart allowance, even though they are deemed unfit for work by their Doctor. Many of these people do not qualify for Disability Support Pension and are placed in Job provider programs that assist them in finding work that is suitable for their condition. However, I have found these to be unsatisfactory. I have consistently found myself in jobs that are not suitable for my condition. I am struggling to hold down a job at present due to my chronic illnesses.

We therefore ask the House to stop placing people with chronic illnesses on Newstart allowance. either amend the existing benefits to better assist people with chronic illnesses or create a benefit that is more suitable.
from 291 citizens (Petition No. EN0915)
Telecommunications: Scams

Mobile phone portability scams are where a scammer contacts a victim's telephone company and requests that their mobile phone number be transferred onto a new SIM card issued either by the same or a different phone provider. This allows the scammer to impersonate the victim by receiving a one-time passcode which is commonly sent by a bank or other company via SMS. The current system of mobile portability, which convenient, does not adequately protect consumers and businesses against these kinds of scams.
We therefore ask the House to
a) refer this matter to the relevant Standing or Select Committee, or to the ACMA, to investigate this issue and to recommend a course of action to prevent these kinds of scams from taking place; and
b) adopt the recommendations stemming from such an inquiry
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN0917)
Religious Freedom

It appears that Christians are routinely mocked and attacked because of their faith, and yet it appears to be acceptable for it to occur. It seems one can express and attempt to force their beliefs on society and not be pulled down, stomped on, vilified and spat upon by society, yet if a Christian even expresses a view or belief based on their religious beliefs, in a public arena they are spread across the media as being a bad person that should be shouted out and shunned. It seems a Christians views that is different from others can be used to attack them. The Christian faith, therefore Christians, can be attacked on public forums and in workplaces, yet there is no punishment for it. For Christians, their faith is the basis for their values, the way they live and bring up their children. Christians do ALOT for their communities, yet there is no protection for them. Why is there no protection for them against harassment, vilification and discrimination? We live in a two-faced society that shuns the very people and groups who do great work for our communities. Wake up Government and do something for these people of faith!!
We therefore ask the House to as soon as possible enact legislation to protect people against harassment, discrimination and vilification in workplaces based on their religious beliefs or views.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN0918)
Assange, Mr Julian

Every child only wants the truth, and as adults, we deserve and demand the truth to be spoken, our expectations are high for the truth to be spoken, judges of the law court room demand the truth to be spoken in order to make the correct judgement in cases, the truth is everyone's right even though it is not always given voluntarily.
We therefore ask the House to give support to one Julian Assange and everyone's right to the freedom of speech to speak the truth.
The request is also for the support of Julian Assange to have the Australian governments support and protection against extradition to the USA on trumped up accusations of crimes.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN0919)
Isaac, Sarah
Native, Australian born from Canberra of Australian citizen parents.
Maladministration and unfair practices, unnecessary time delays and hinderance without direct cause.
Expressed concerns of mismanagement and mistreatment by the Department of Home Affairs, and Department of Foreign Affairs.
We therefore ask the House to support Sarah Isaac's native by birth Australian passport and citizenship acquisition.
from 1 citizen (Petition No. EN0920)
Human Rights: Children
Dear sir/madam,

I am writing this as there is an epidemic of men committing suicide in Australia over custody right of their children and children being withheld from biological fathers, fathers of Australia demand a speedier process and that woman who withheld their children receive harsh punishments as this is a form of domestic violence, the fathers of Australia demand justice and true equal rights to their children.

We therefore ask the House to put a royal commission in place to investigate or put laws in place to give fathers rights to access their children and to stop mothers putting unjust avo's in place just out of spite and denying men their paternal rights.
from 212 citizens (Petition No. EN0921)
Legal Aid
Cali Jade 0 Comments
0 SignatureGoal: 1,000
This petition is to rally numbers to bring in a new law to protect our children and families with a genuine need for Legal Aid regarding family law matters.
Proposal:

That, "If a person has a history of abuse towards children, or has been convicted of a violent crime, has served time in prison for a violent crime, has any sexual related offences that they have been charged for or has legitiment violent breeches on a domestic violence order that they are unable to obtain Legal Aid for Family Law Matters only. (Yes they can still claim Legal Aid for criminal matters e.t.c.) This will protect our children on another level, save the state millions of dollars and ensure there is enough funding for victims of crime especially to receive the financial support they need to protect themselves.

Legal Aid are denying families help within regards to family lawyers due to a "lack of funding". If you have a history of violence to towards children or anyone why should the tax payers fund offenders with family lawyers. The system has to start supporting the right people.
We therefore ask the House to bring this in as new legislation and make it an official law nationally within Australia
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN0922)
Indigenous Australians

Since the colonisation of Australia, Human Rights have been overlooked for European global dominance, western structures and governance. In our current age of awareness and understanding, empathy in leadership is needed. I, along with many, believe in a change to the norm. As a middle-aged white male, the lineage of the asserted dominance, I plead with all politicians to listen. We need to change our approach to managing indigenous families and children. With the right governance and time, we could be the most desired and admired country in the world. We just need the right leaders.
We therefore ask the House to listen without reluctance.

Australia is one of the few, truly lucky countries in the world. But colonisation has a lot to answer for. We have an opportunity to right the wrongs if we listen and approach change with empathy and respect. By creating equality and adopting a new way of governance and expenditure, we could be the country that acts to enable change for the world through intelligent, empathetic leadership. It's no longer possible to govern Indigenous Australians under our current western platform. History and statistics make that crystal clear. What I ask, is for you to make a change to the system, fundamentally. Incorporate a National Indigenous Representative Body as proposed in 2008 for Federal Government. Secondly, create Indigenous governing bodies for each State and Territory. Create a Treaty and work with Indigenous Australians to repair the damage done through western governance.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN0923)
Political Advertising

This petition is asking the government and the Australian Electoral Commission to review the amount of political advertising one party can release during an election. It also asks to update the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to prevent any future parties using their personal wealth to have the loudest voice.
For example the UAP has spent 27 million on political ads on radio, TV, Facebook. YouTube inundating every available platform with an oversaturation of advertising.
We therefore ask the House to update the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to reflect on it's advertising rules and moderating how much can be spent.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN0927)
Blood Donation

At the memory Australia needs blood. There are so many gay men who wish to donate but cannot because of having a sexual partner in the last 12 months. This means people in relationships must abstain from sexual contact for 12 months even if they use condoms or PrEP to reduce their risk of HIV. This van needs to be more lenient for gay men.
We therefore ask the House to reconsider their current 12 month ban for gay men donating blood.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN0928)
Political Parties: Campaign Policies

A lack of transparency and public perception of honesty within Federal Government, particularly surrounding Federal Election periods, due to apparently untenable election promises made by a Party or Parties to the public of Australia, and a lack of consistent, visible stance on important issues.

We therefore ask the House to develop a public resource (i.e. a website or other form of easily accessible forum), overseen by a non-partisan Federal department, that all Parties running in elections must provide information to on:
/ The Party's policies, clearly and succinctly laid out for the Australian public, in regards to important domestic issues and events.
/ The Party's policies, clearly and succinctly laid out for the Australian public, in regards to important international issues that involve Australia.
/ The Party's election promises, with an estimated expected arrival time on those promises for the Australian public.
/ Any Bills the Party intends in advance to propose during its term to the House for the Australian public.
/ The Party's stance on social, political, and economic events or issues involving Australia, regardless of the Party's intention to take action on said events or issues.
/ The Party's intention, if it has any, to take action on the latter mentioned events or issues.

We request this resource to provide a system that requires Parties to provide all available information pertaining to the above-mentioned artefacts, in a manner by which the Party cannot request the information be removed without amending it, thereby ensuring that all pertinent policy data is available to the Australian public.
from 8 citizens (Petition No. EN0929)
Video Games Industry

Many modern video games, both on mobile phones, and specialised gaming consoles, are made to be addictive, but feature slow progression requiring either boring and long repetition know as grinding, or purchasing, with real money, ways to accelerate progression, known as micro-transactions. A common example is known as a 'lootbox', containing a small random assortment of in game items, gambling your own money away in the hopes of progression in the game. These games are designed to be addictive and slow, and to suck people into making further purchases, in games that you may have already paid $100 to buy in the first place. They are casinos dolled up to look like toys, made by companies who know they can make more money from making addictive games that break you down into making micro-transactions, than they can make by making compelling games you only pay for once.
We therefore ask the House to look into these games, and to take reasonable steps to prevent their preying on children and people's addictive nature.
from 8 citizens (Petition No. EN0930)
Federal Government: Fixed Terms
Asking the house to extend federal government terms to at least 4 years.
We therefore ask the House to consider this petition.
from 1 citizen (Petition No. EN0931)
Federal Electoral System
We the petitioners want a change in our electoral system.
First Preference is simple for House of Reps where you vote for the candidate of your choice for your seat a simple #1.

In the Senate It should be up to the elector how many they vote for, but they should vote 1 to 6 who they want but if they vote above the line for Lib, ALP or whoever then only their representatives are voted for in these seats. Smaller parties and independents will still get a vote for a seat but only the one seat unless they have more candidates who can be counted under the party vote. No preferences involved but if you receive a vote the number of votes will determine if you win a state seat in the federal senate.

Still a lot easier than at present, first past the post in force and we get rid of the party booths handing out how to vote cards to people as preferences don’t count. Anyone who does not vote for all seats simply must accept their candidate may only win the one seat if they get the numbers, and any extra seats they did not vote for but this is their choice.
We therefore ask the House to move to change the electoral system in Australia into a fairer system for all Electors. The First preference system is the system this petition is referring to.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN0932)
Climate Change

The undeniable truth is that we continue to do great damage to the planet and we haven’t learnt how to grow our economy without harming nature. In the past 50 years, truly a blink of an eye compared to the more than 2 million years of our species’ history, we have seen an exponential acceleration of the unsustainable and wasteful use of natural resources. If we continue to produce, consume and power our lives the way we do right now, forests, oceans and weather systems could be overwhelmed and irreversibly damaged
We therefore ask the House to Ban the use of unsustainable resources and introduce sustainable Eco friendly resources.
from 6 citizens (Petition No. EN0933)
Education

We no-longer live in the dark-ages, 2-3,000-years-ago; meaning, terrorists use violence for a political purpose, to protect their ancient belief and faith in ‘who’ made us, that ACT, “Is no-longer fit for purpose.” CHANGE HAS ARRIVED: Our belief and faith in all Children in all Cultures, involves devotion, discipline, support and encouragement for those Children, to receive the “Human-Evolution” ‘Proven-Facts’ about anatomical changes to their body organisms during the past 3.95 Billions-years; that Education process will design a legal moral-code to ‘correctly govern’ the conduct of Human-affairs. “Please support our belief and faith in all Children.

We therefore ask the House to debate this 'EDUCATION BILL: Education Act, to be amended. Section 1: Introduce one Subject, H-E.E.L. (HUMAN-EVOLUTION EDUCATION LAW) competently Educating all Students in every Australian School-Culture, building a high-quality early Childhood Education for those Students, on their journey through School, and University; that law of principle will rule one, (COMPULSORY SEPARATE CURRICULUM) ‘in grades 1 to 12, for those Students in ‘ALL’ School-cultures, to receive the Scientific Proven-Facts about, (HUMAN-EVOLUTION) ‘Compassionately touched and designed for every Public School, Private School, religious School, and Independent Schools.
OR, hold a referendum; (Vote, YES) Human-Evolution Education;” (Vote, NO) Human-Evolution Education.
from 1 citizen (Petition No. EN0934)
Cybercrime Act 2001

All Australians have an implied right to silence so that they may not be forced to testify against themselves. This common law right is important in upholding the freedom of Australian citizens and allows them to not have their rights abused.

However, Items 12 and 28 of the Cybercrime Act 2001 No. 161 are legal loopholes that infringe on the right that the Australian people deserve to refuse to give testimony and/or potentially provide self-incriminating information. Not only is penalizing Australian citizens for refusing to provide encryption keys/passwords to police arguably morally abhorrent, it is also completely unnecessary.

It is known to many Australian citizens that police are readily able to perform digital forensics on various forms of computer storage in order to gather evidence by means of specialized software and physical tools. This can and should be done without the need of a citizen to provide their passwords, as police should not be compelling assistance from an individual to decrypt data that may incriminate them.
Similarly to how one is not required to invite police into their home, they shouldn't be required to invite them into their device. If police need to enter then they can by their own means.
We therefore ask the House to remove Items 12 and 28 from the Cybercrime Act 2001 No. 161.
from 52 citizens (Petition No. EN0938)
Health Care
To improve survival rates and quality of life outcomes in those persons who suffer a cardiac arrest.
Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest is a major Public Health Issue. It has been described as the most time-sensitive and life threatening medical condition.

In Australia each year there are 30,000 people who collapse from a cardiac arrest with only 9-10% of those surviving. It is also estimated that 95% of all cardiac arrest die before reaching hospital. This equates to 27,000 deaths, approximately, more than triple that of breast, prostate and skin cancers combined.

Research has clearly demonstrated the key role of bystander CPR and defibrillation in minimising the discrete interval from collapse to the commencement of chest compressions in affecting positive survival outcomes. If there is no intervention, CPR and or defibrillation, within four minutes of the cardiac arrest occurring the person will have brain damage and is unlikely to survive after ten minutes. Survival after a cardiac arrest decreases dramatically by 7-10% with every minute that defibrillation is delayed.
Every Second Counts.

We therefore ask the House to consider Mandatory CPR Training for Years six and seven school students and CPR Training including the use of an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) for those students in Years ten and thereafter.
from 253 citizens (Petition No. EN0939)
Telecommunications

We are deeply concerned about the coming rollout of 5G. 5G is untested and the health effects are unknown. However what is known is that EMR is toxic and very harmful to the health of humans. 5G is not an upgraded 4G but a completely new technology. Extremely high frequency wavelengths will be emitted. 5G towers need to be every 100- 500 metres. Concentrated and focused electromagnetic radiation will be emitted at much higher levels. It will mean the radio waves will be inescapable , leading to involuntary exposure to radiation. We will have no choice but to be exposed to the radiation. The last time testing was carried out was in 2002 (even before the implementation of 4G) and against a Senate Committee Recommendation of 200 microwatts. There is a total lack of transparency and safety information on 5G technology. Rome and Brussels have stopped the role out of 5G .
We therefore ask the House to implement a Moratorium on the 5G rollout.
We ask for the ARPANSA safety standards to be completely reviewed and updated, in line with worldwide research and safety standards.

We urge you to consider the Precautionary Principle, and use it to justify discretionary decisions in situations where there is the possibility of harm, specifically when extensive scientific knowledge on this matter is lacking. The principle implies that there is a responsibility to protect the public from exposure to harm, when scientific investigation has found a plausible risk.
from 375 citizens (Petition No. EN0942)
Water

We need more dams and water carriers in Australia to harness the water that is wasted, we have to become water independent because we have such a dry continent. To much money is wasted on unnecessary things in this country the government has to start looking after their own people and country, Mps who are paid to go and find other solutions to problems should do so instead of just having holidays...We need the government to get down to work and fix our water problems!
We therefore ask the House to vote for New Dams that will make this continent water independent...
from 7 citizens (Petition No. EN0945)
Commonwealth Electoral System
WHEREAS the sole legal function of a Member of Parliament is to freely advise the Queen in the government of the Country according to the clearly expressed will of the people.

AND WHEREAS most Members of Parliament take the attitude that a representative of the people is not a delegate of the people, where a delegate is someone that the people have delegated power to and set what policies their Member should have, and a representative gets to exercise their own judgement and implement what they deem best, even if its in direct opposition to the clearly expressed will of the people of their electorate.

AND WHEREAS this leads to a situation where a Member of Parliament is the sole determiner of what should or should not be placed before parliament by the member - generally based on their political parties objectives and independent of the will of electors

We therefore ask the House to act immediately to provide a satisfactory remedy for this obvious defect in our democracy in the Commonwealth, by providing, in our electoral and referendum system, as other strong democracies around the world have done, for:
a) Recall Elections: a procedure by which electors can remove a duly elected Member of Parliament from office, through a direct vote, before that member's term has ended.

b) Initiatives: a means by which a electors can force the parliament to enact, repeal, amend a law, or trigger a referendum on a topic, clearly mandated by the people outside of the existing parliamentary processes.
from 5 citizens (Petition No. EN0946)
Endometriosis
Endometriosis is an incurable, debilitating disease affecting over 700,000 Australian women. The medications to help with management are very expensive.
We therefore ask the House to include endometriosis related medications such as Visanne and Yaz Flex on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
from 531 citizens (Petition No. EN0947)
Members of Parliament: Allegiance

WHEREAS the oath or affirmation of allegiance that every member of parliament makes and subscribes before taking their seat in parliament requires them to be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty. (Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act 1900)
AND WHEREAS the Queen during her coronation, promised to the utmost of Her power, to maintain the Laws of God and the true profession of the Gospel. (Coronation oath Act 1688)

AND WHEREAS all the Kings and Queens who administer the Government according to the said Laws and all their Officers and Ministers ought to serve them respectively according to the same. (Act of Settlement 1700)

AND WHEREAS the Holy Bible is the most valuable thing that this world affords; the wisdom , the royal Law, the lively Oracles of God and the Rule for the whole life and government of Christian Princes, the law and the Gospel of God. (The Form and Order of Service in the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II)

THEREFORE in summary, we have a Holy Book, that details the law and the Gospel of God, a monarch who has promised to maintain them, and ministers and officers that are to be faithful and bear true allegiance to the monarch in administrating the Government, according to the said Laws.

We therefore ask the House to act immediately to provide clarification on the status of the “law and the Gospel of God”, in the administration and authority of the Commonwealth, and the obligations of the elected Members of Parliament towards them.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN0948)
Road Vehicle Standards

Requesting that the House consider changes to the national legislation and the ADR(57) to alleviate vexatious regulations regarding motorcycle handlebar heights. It is our submission that laws should be unified as they relate to vehicles manufactured pre and post 1988; specifically that the current compliance height of 380mm be measured from the point of attachment to the vehicle rather than the uppermost surface of the riders seat.

It is our belief that the reformation of these laws will lead to greater rider wellbeing, increased freedom of modification and the subsequent benefit to industry, reduced cost impost on motorcycle manufacturers and consumers without reducing safety.

We therefore ask the House to consider amendments to the Motor Vehicles Standards Act, the National Code of Practice for Vehicle Construction and aid in the amendment of the Australian Design Rules pertaining to motorcycle construction. Specifically to effect laws requiring all mopeds, motorcycles and motor trikes, regardless of manufacture date, to comply with a handlebar height of 380mm measured from the point of attachment to the vehicle, as per the currect legislation pertaining to vehicles manufactured prior to June 30, 1988.
from 3858 citizens (Petition No. EN0950)
Vaccination
In July, Robert F Kennedy jr, AntiVax advocate is planning on visiting Australia and holding a public seminar on July 5 in Brisbane.
We hereby ask the honourable parliament of Australia to deny Mr Kennedy jr’s access to Australia, to promote this public health attack on vaccines and vaccinations.
It is clear that Australia is at the forefront in the world regarding healthcare and disease prevention.

The access for Mr Kennedy jr to spread an unscientific message that is Anti-Vaccine, not only flies in the face of current vaccine and medical science, but is promoting a concept that will potentially:
• cause more people to stop vaccinating
• cause more public health expenditure on outbreaks (such as the current USA Measles outbreak)
• diminish Australia’s goals for herd immunity
• bring back previously eradicated diseases in Australia.
We therefore ask the House to block access for Mr Robert F. Kennedy jr from entering Australia to spread fake news and pseudoscience.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN0951)
Skilled Migration Visas

Hong Kong

The proposed Extradition Bill of Hong Kong could allow political dissidents/non-conformists to be extradited to China, which is problematic because they will likely face unjust treatments for merely expressing their opinions. As of the writing of this petition, the Hong Kong government has merely suspended the proposal, despite overwhelming public disapproval.

Furthermore, in the protest against the bill on June 12, the Hong Kong police used overwhelming force that was more lethal than required to disperse the peaceful protestors. This included indiscriminate use of teargas, pepper-sprays, rubber rounds, and batons against unarmed persons. The Hong Kong government is determined to charge activists for “rioting”, despite the lack of collective violence on behalf of protestors, and despite the fact that the police was the predominant perpetrator of lethal violence.

Freedom of expression and fairness are two fundamentally Australian values. As Australians, we ought to speak up against any threats to these values. Furthermore, 100,000 Australians currently reside in Hong Kong, and more than 600 Australian businesses operate there. The Australian government must stand united with the international community to demonstrate our resolve against human right violation, and protect all Australians from injustice.
We therefore ask the House to:
1. In the upcoming G20 Summit, denounce the extradition bill, and demand the Hong Kong government to fully withdraw its proposal
2. In light of Hong Kong’s human rights situation, reassess the Australia-Hong Kong Free Trade Agreement, to serve the best interest of Australians who are vital stakeholders of this agreement

from 185 citizens (Petition No. EN0978)
Commonwealth Electoral Act
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives.
We the undersigned petitioners believe the electoral system needs changing to restore voter confidence and democratic integrity.

In the 2016 federal election, over 18,000 people breached the Electoral Act by voting more than once. In the recent 2019 federal election, paper electoral rolls - not able to be cross-checked, allowed voters more than one vote. No voter identification was required giving an opportunity to vote under another person’s name and address. Counting of ballot papers continued to be subject to ‘human error’. To cast a formal vote under Mandatory Preferential Voting (MPV) voters were forced to number every square on the ballot paper.
In a modern digital world, our electoral system remains firmly in the previous century. In one of the worlds’ oldest democracies, MPV is not democratic.
It is time for Australia to change to online and ‘optional preferential voting’ (OPV). This will help deliver accurate and timely electoral results and restore voters’ confidence.
We therefore ask the House to enact the following changes ready for the 2022 Federal Election;
1/ Provide Electronic Rolls at ALL polling booths
2/ Issue voter identification (ID) as a requirement to vote
3/ Activate secure online electronic voting (OEV)
4/ Reduce numbers of booths and pre-polling period to two weeks
5/ Change to a more democratic Optional Preferential Voting (OPV) system for the House of Representative

We the undersigned petitioners request a debate on nuclear energy production to address increasing costs and lack of baseload electricity.

The forced closure of several coal-fired power stations has removed significant baseload energy from the national grid. To reduce emissions and meet the Paris Climate Agreement, over $3b of taxpayer subsidies are ‘invested’ annually in renewable energy businesses; 60% of them overseas owned. In the states of Victoria and South Australia, high levels of ‘renewables’ have caused major electricity blackouts severely impacting industry, business and communities.

Demand for more heavily subsidized renewables to address ‘climate change’ has resulted in other forms of energy production being overlooked.

With large deposits of uranium and thorium, advanced modulized plants with zero emissions, plus options for the disposal of minimum waste, it is time for an open and honest debate about nuclear energy in Australia.
We therefore ask the House to initiate a Parliamentary Inquiry into the possibility of nuclear energy production in Australia and to make these findings publicly available.
We request that nuclear power plants in Australia, be Australian owned.

from 92 citizens (Petition No. EN0992)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:01): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
National Memorial
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 2 January 2019 to the Hon Peter Dutton MP, Minister for Home Affairs, regarding petition number EN0255. Your letter was forwarded to me as I am the minister responsible for the matter you raised. I apologise for the delay in replying.
I understand that this petition refers to a proposal for a permanent national memorial for all the victims of terrorists both internationally and domestic.

The Canberra National Memorials Committee (CNMC) which is established by the National Memorials Ordinance Act 1928 makes decisions regarding the siting and form of memorials in national areas of Canberra. The Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, chairs this committee.

The National Capital Authority (NCA) is the Australian Government agency responsible for the ongoing planning and development of Canberra as the National Capital. The NCA has been central to the development of memorials and monuments in the National Capital. The NCA also provides secretariat services to the CNMC and makes recommendations to it regarding individual memorial proposals.
The NCA has not received a formal application from the group proposing to construct this memorial. As such neither the NCA nor the CNMC has formally considered the proposal.

Any proposal for a commemorative work, such as a memorial, received by the NCA is assessed against the principles described in its Guidelines for Commemorative Works in the National Capital. The stages employ:
Mandatory Criteria that determine if the subject can be considered for commemoration in the National Capital; and
Evaluation Criteria that determine if the subject has 'national significance' and should be commemorated in the National Capital to ensure the proposed memorial meets both mandatory criteria.

The NCA will provide project management services for agreed commemorative works proposals including; the management of design competitions, design development and management of construction with physical construction costs usually borne by the proponent.
Further information on the Guidelines for Commemorative Works in the National Capital can be found at www.nca.gov.au/sites/default/files/publication-documents/CommemGuidelines.pdf.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to the Australian Government's attention and I trust this is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Territories, the Hon. Sussan Ley MP(Petition No. EN0255)
Great Barrier Reef
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for providing petition EN0726, concerning Adani's Carmichael Coal Mine and Rail Project (the Project) in Queensland and its impacts on the Great Barrier Reef (the Reef).

The Australian Government (the Government) is firmly committed to protecting the Reef and the 64,000 jobs it supports. We are doing this through sound policy, substantial direct investment and world class marine park management.

Additionally, the Australian and Queensland governments released an updated Reef 2050 Plan in July 2018. The plan is supported by a joint $2 billion investment, including funding for expanding environmental management and compliance operations on the reef.

In relation to the request for 'the House to implement laws restricting Adani from undertaking coal mining across the Great Barrier Reef' The mine will not have any direct impacts on the Reef as it is located around 300 km west of the Reef. Ships travelling through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park may only navigate within a designated shipping area and General Use zones if they obtain a permit from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

The Project is also subject to over 180 environmental conditions from state and Commonwealth regulators. Adani's compliance with conditions under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) will be monitored by the Department of the Environment and Energy's Office of Compliance. Adani is to annually publish a compliance report on its website and provide me with a copy. If needed, I can direct that an independent audit of compliance be conducted.

In regards to the request 'that a form of action be carried out and awareness of the issue of coal mining across the Reef be widely publicised'. Any decision on projects assessed under the EPBC Act, and the conditions for approved projects, is provided on the Department's website.
Thank you for bringing petition EN0726 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, the Hon. Melissa Price MP (Petition No. EN0726)
Visas
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 November 2018 regarding a petition received (EN0733). The petition related to the refusal of Visitor visa applications for Syrian and Lebanese nationals seeking to visit family in Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Australia's Visitor visa programme is administered on a global and non-discriminatory basis and during the 2017-18 financial year, the Department of Home Affairs granted 5,639,167 Visitor visas for travel to Australia. Departmental officers apply the same legal criteria to all applications that must be processed in accordance with the Migration Act and Regulations. There is no discretion for processing officers to depart from these requirements.

Visitor visas are available for people to visit Australia for a holiday, sightseeing, social or recreational reasons, to visit relatives, friends or for business visitor activities. There are various legal requirements that must be met by an applicant before a Visitor visa can be granted, this includes, among other things, that the applicant has adequate funds for support for the period of the visit and intends a genuine temporary stay in Australia.

When deciding whether an applicant intends a genuine temporary stay in Australia, the decision maker must take into account relevant considerations such as the applicant's personal circumstances, incentive to return home, financial situation and ability to support themselves while in Australia. The likelihood of an applicant overstaying or seeking to remain in Australia also must be assessed.

An applicant's country of origin is not itself a factor that is considered when assessing if an applicant's intention is to stay temporarily in Australia. However, the circumstances and environment in an applicant's home country may contribute to a judgement that, on balance, an applicant does not genuinely intend to stay temporarily in Australia.

The petition requested that the Department ask more questions from an applicant before refusing their application. As the Department is able to consider a visa application based solely on the documentation and information provided with the application, it is important that a Visitor visa applicant provide as much information as possible with the application. Further information on the type of documents that can be provided for a Visitor visa can be found on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/visitor-600/tourist-stream-onshore#HowTo.

I can assure the petitioners that decisions on visa applications are made only after full and careful consideration and in accordance with Australia's migration legislation. Under the migration legislation, the decision maker must refuse an application if they are not satisfied that the applicant meets the prescribed criteria for a visa.

A decision to refuse a Visitor visa may be eligible to be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). Further information on this process can be found in the Department's notification of decision letter and also on the AATs website at: http://www.aat.gov.au/migration-and-refugee-division/applying-for-a-review.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. David Coleman MP (Petition No. EN0733)
Christian Festivals
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for advising me of the petition (EN0740) received by the Standing Committee on Petitions on 26 November 2018, asking the House to recognise the traditions of Christmas and Easter, encouraging them to be openly celebrated across all sectors of Australian society.

Christmas and Easter have long been, and continue to be, a very important time of the year for many Australians and are celebrated by people of many different faiths. Australia's approach to multicultural affairs supports freedom of thought, speech, religion and association - including the celebration of key Christian days.
There are several ways in which the significance of Christmas and Easter continue to be recognised by the Australian Government.

In Australia, Good Friday, Easter Monday and Christmas Day are three of the seven National Public Holidays (the other four are New Year's Day, Australia Day, Boxing Day and Anzac Day). Most states and territories also have legislated restricted shop trading days for Good Friday and Christmas Day. No other religions have their most significant days either recognized as National Public Holidays or acknowledged with restricted trading hours.

On 27 June 2018, the Australian Senate referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure a proposal to replace the tradition of reciting the Lord's Prayer at the start of Parliamentary sessions with an invitation for prayer or reflection. The inquiry report was delivered on 13 September 2018, recommending that the current practice of reading the Lord's Prayer be maintained as the vast majority of more than 800 submissions to the inquiry opposed the proposed changes.

In 2017, Senator the Hon Eric Abetz called for a review of Christmas and Easter messages from Government department heads to their staffs. The vast majority wished their staff 'Merry Christmas' and 'Happy Easter', rather than a religiously neutral 'Happy Holidays'. Meanwhile, while the Prime Minister and other ministers do send Eid messages, they also send Merry Christmas messages, including video messages to Australian troops overseas.

At the same time, schools and business leaders have autonomy in managing matters related to celebrations and festivals, including Christian celebrations, through respectful relationships with their employees and school communities.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. David Coleman MP (Petition No. EN0740)
Goods and Services Tax
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 November 2018, originally directed to the Treasurer, regarding petition number EN0744 to call a Royal Commission into fuel prices and gouging, reduce fuel excise and remove the goods and services tax (GST) on fuel. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me.

Fuel prices are influenced by many factors, including overseas and local market forces. Key factors include changes in international benchmark prices, the value of the Australian dollar, levels of competition in different areas and pricing decisions by wholesalers and retailers. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) monitors retail fuel prices on a daily basis and where it sees issues of concern, it investigates. This oversight negates the need for a Royal Commission, as prices and gouging are already being monitored.

Fuel excise raises revenue for the Government. It is a relatively stable source of revenue, efficient and easy to administer. Fuel excise rates are indexed in line with the consumer price index (CPI) and in Australia, are lower than the OECD average. While road taxes are not earmarked to road spending, revenue from these taxes generally covers the direct cost of infrastructure spending on roads and bridges. The Government is not considering a reduction of fuel excise at this time.

The GST applies broadly to goods and services with a limited number of exemptions in areas such as food, education and medical services. Some goods and services are GST-free because imposing GST would be technically difficult or would create inequities between private and public sector providers.

When the GST was introduced, the Government reduced fuel excise so the price for consumers did not rise. Extending the range of GST-free goods and services to areas such as fuel would impact adversely on the ability of state and territory governments to provide essential services to the community.
I trust this information is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, the Hon. Stuart Robert MP(Petition No. EN0744)
Climate Change
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter regarding the petition on reducing our greenhouse emissions (EN0756) received by the Petitions Committee.

The Australian Government (the Government) remains committed to the Paris Agreement and meeting its 2030 target to reduce emissions to 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels. This target is responsible and represents one of the most ambitious reductions in per capita emissions and emissions per unit of GDP among developed countries.

The Government is integrating climate science into decision-making as a key principle of good environmental policy. The Government's National Environmental Science Programme (NESP) supports environmental and climate research to inform decisions by businesses, communities and governments. NESP is strengthening national research capability in climate science and other fields through prioritisation and streamlining delivery.

The Government has a comprehensive set of policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, increase energy efficiency and fast track development and uptake of clean energy. The Emissions Reduction Fund (ERF) is the centrepiece of the Government's response, supporting a range of emissions reduction opportunities across the economy. To date, 190 million tonnes of abatement have been purchased from 423 ERF projects across Australia.

The Safeguard Mechanism places limits on Australia's largest emitters, covering half of our national emissions. The National Energy Productivity Plan will improve energy productivity by 40 per cent between 2015 and 2030.

The Renewable Energy Target is a key driver in encouraging the uptake of renewables and is on track to generate at least 23.5 per cent of Australia's electricity supply in 2020. Last year, approximately 15 per cent of Australia's electricity generation was from renewable sources; one third from wind, one third from hydro-electricity and a quarter from solar.

Major investments are made through the Australian Renewable Energy Agency and the Clean Energy Finance Corporation, to manage the ongoing transition to lower emissions in the energy sector. Other measures include action to reduce emissions from harmful hydrofluorocarbons.

Internationally, Australia is playing a strong role. We have joined other countries, including China, Japan and India on the Mission Innovation initiative to increase investment in clean energy R&D. We are a founding member of the International Coral Reef Initiative and the International Partnership for Blue Carbon.
Thank you for bringing the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, the Hon. Melissa Price MP (Petition No. EN0756)
Defence: Superannuation
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 18 February 2019 about Petition EN0758. The petition seeks changes to the Military Superannuation and Benefits (MSB) scheme to allow Australian Defence Force members who have a preserved employer benefit in the MSB scheme to roll over their employer benefit to another fund of their choice.

The benefit in the MSB scheme is comprised of a member benefit and an employer benefit. The member benefit is fully indexed and invested in the member's nominated investment division (or divisions). The employer benefit includes a funded employer component (productivity contributions) and an unfunded component. The funded employer component is invested in the default investment division and the unfunded component grows in line with positive movements in the Consumer Price Index.

A MSB scheme member who leaves the permanent forces (and is not undertaking continuous full-time service in the Reserves) must preserve their employer benefit in the scheme until age 55. The employer benefit is largely unfunded and when payment falls due, the unfunded component is paid from Consolidated Revenue. The member benefit can be rolled over to another fund at any time after a member leaves the permanent forces.

The inability to roll over the employer benefit (where funds are payable from Consolidated Revenue) is consistent with the other Commonwealth defined benefit schemes. Any consideration given to allowing MSB scheme members the ability to roll over their unfunded employer component could potentially have a flow-on effect to these schemes.

Any move to provide access to the employer benefit prior to age 55 would require the Government to fund these benefits immediately. The Australian Government Actuary provided advice on 30 June 2017 in the Long Term Cost Report that the value of the unfunded employer benefit for preserved members in the MSB scheme was $10 billion.

Recommendation 8 of the Report of the Review in Military Superannuation Arrangements (commonly known as the Podger Review) was "Preserved members of the MSBS should be given the option, for a limited period, to have the current face value of their benefit funded and then taxed on transfer to the new scheme, or to a scheme of their choice." The Podger Review recommended the closure of the MSB scheme and for it to be replaced with an accumulation scheme. The ADF Super accumulation scheme was introduced in July 2016. When implementing the scheme not all the recommendations from the Podger Review were implemented, including Recommendation 8.

Should consideration be given to allow earlier access to the employer benefit, it could lead to detrimental changes to the overall benefit design of the scheme by potentially reducing the benefits and pensions payable for the remaining members. As the scheme is a defined benefit scheme, the benefits are actuarially based on members claiming their benefits on or after the age of 55.

From age 55, members with a preserved employer benefit can elect to receive a lifetime indexed pension. Should a member elect to purchase a lifetime indexed pension, it will revert to an eligible spouse (for the rest of their lifetime) and/or children (for the period they remain eligible) on the death of the member. If members were able to roll over their employer benefit to another fund, they would forgo their entitlement to a lifetime fully indexed pension. I am advised it would take a considerably larger sum in the private sector to purchase a comparable pension.
The Government has no plans to change the preservation arrangements for the MSB scheme members at this time.
I trust this information is of assistance to you and the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Personnel and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Centenary of Anzac, the Hon. Darren Chester MP(Petition No. EN0758)
Prime Minister
Dear Mrs Wicks
I refer to your letter of 18 February 2019 regarding petition number EN0762 concerning guaranteed four-year terms for the Prime Minister of Australia.
I note that neither the Australian Government, nor the Attorney-General, provides legal advice to the public. However, the following general comments may be of assistance.

Despite its importance, the Constitution does not mention the position of Prime Minister. The Governor-General has the power to appoint and to dismiss a Prime Minister. These are known as 'reserve powers'. In exercising a reserve power, the Governor-General ordinarily acts in accordance with established and generally accepted rules of practice known as `conventions'. For example, when appointing a Prime Minister under section 64 of the Constitution, the Governor-General must, by convention, appoint a person who has the confidence of the House of Representatives. That condition is fulfilled if the Governor-General appoints as Prime Minister the parliamentary leader of the party or coalition of parties which has a majority of seats in the House of Representatives.

The Prime Minister is not directly elected by the Australian electorate. Rather, the electors vote for members of parliament to sit in the House of Representatives and the Senate, who choose the leaders of their parties. This is consistent with the principle of representative government which is a fundamental underlying principle of the Australian Constitution. The Australian Government is not proposing any change to the current arrangements for the appointment or dismissal of a Prime Minister.
The Constitution provides for each House of Representatives to continue for up to three years, but no longer. Senators are generally elected for six-year terms.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, the Hon. Christian Porter MP(Petition No. EN0762)
Climate Change
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 18 February 2019 to the Hon Melissa Price MP, Minister for the Environment concerning Petition EN0766 regarding funding to the Green Climate Fund (GCF). As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities your letter has been referred to me for reply.

Australia committed $200 million to the Green Climate Fund from 2014 to 2018. It is important we ensure this funding is managed appropriately and supports Australia's regional interests. However, Australia is not planning to provide further funding to the GCF. It is our assessment there are significant challenges with the GCF's governance and operational model which impact on its effectiveness.

The Australian Government remains strongly committed to supporting countries in the Indo-Pacific to build their climate resilience. We believe we can deliver more effective results for our region by working directly with our neighbours and with effective partners. Australia is committed to spending at least $300 million over four years (2016-17 to 2019-20) on climate and disaster resilience support to the Pacific and we have already contributed nearly $200 million in the past two years.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon. Marise Payne(Petition No. EN0766)
Internet
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 28 February 2019 on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions about Petition EN0773 calling for a 'Digital Bill of Rights'.

The Australian Government is committed to promoting the rule of law and the rights and protections we enjoy as a democratic nation. Of these, our right to free speech and free expression is one of the most highly-valued and fiercely protected. The ability of citizens to speak freely and openly is the hallmark of a robust democracy, and these rights should extend to the online world. These rights, however, should be balanced with the need to protect Australians, particularly children, from being exposed to harmful content online.

The Government is committed to enhancing the online safety of all Australians by ensuring there are proper regulatory controls and support systems in place to mitigate risks and allow Australians to confidently take advantage of the benefits of the digital environment.- Put simply, the Government believes that the standards of behaviour that apply offline should be the same as those that apply online.

There are a number of existing laws and initiatives that aim to uphold this principle. The Online Content Scheme (set out in Schedules 5 and 7 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992), for example, regulates prohibited or potentially prohibited online content in Australia based on the National Classification Scheme. Content is assessed on the basis of a public complaint to the Office of the eSafety Commissioner, which has the power to remove or prevent access to prohibited content, which includes child abuse images, pornography, and terrorist-related material.

Changes in technology are rapid, and it is vital that legislation is able to adequately respond to the challenges presented by this continually evolving digital environment. The recently-tabled report of the review of the Enhancing Online Safety Act 2015 and the Online Content Scheme (Briggs Review) made a number of recommendations for changes to the online safety framework, including consolidating the Online Content

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is also currently conducting an inquiry into digital platform providers, which will look at the impact that social media platforms, digital search engines, and digital content aggregation platforms are having on competition in media and advertising services markets.

Large technology firms are extremely influential within our economy and community, so it is essential that they understand community needs and expectations. Social media sites, including Facebook and Google, have terms of use which govern the relationship with users and others who interact with their sites. For example, by using or accessing Facebook, you agree to its Statement of Rights and Responsibilities, which includes certain obligations relating to online safety.

I note the petitioners' sentiment, however, that more needs to be done to make the internet a safer place for all Australians. Whilst the Government does not plan to introduce a 'Digital Bill of Rights', it is committed to encouraging greater transparency and accountability amongst technology firms, and is therefore currently consulting on a draft Online Safety Charter (the Charter). The Charter sets out the Government's expectations, on behalf of the community, of digital platforms in reducing online harm. This includes the Government's expectations with regard to the removal of offensive content, the earlier identification of illegal and harmful content, complaint and compliance reporting, and stricter controls on accounts.

I very much encourage those who signed this petition to make a submission to the Charter consultation through the following link: www.communications.gov.au/have-your-say/online-safety-charter-consultation.

The Australian Government is aware of recent concerns surrounding Facebook and the possible misuse of personal information, which was one of the issues raised by the petition. On 5 April 2018, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) announced that it had opened a formal investigation into Facebook, following confirmation from Facebook that the information of over 300,000 Australian users may have been acquired and used without authorisation.

The OAIC's investigation will consider whether Facebook has breached the Privacy Act 1988 (the Privacy Act). The Privacy Act regulates organisations and agencies that operate in Australia, including major social media platforms such as Facebook that are headquartered overseas, but have an 'Australian link'. Given the global nature of the matter, the OAIC has stated that it will confer with regulatory authorities internationally.

The ACCC's inquiry into the Australian digital market has a specific focus on the impact of digital platforms on the supply of news and journalistic content. The Inquiry will consider what consumers understand about the price that they are paying to use Faeebook; what data Facebook collects; how it is used and whether consumers are being misled. The Government welcomes the ACCC's final report due in June 2019 and will consider its recommendations carefully.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator the Hon. Mitch Fifield(Petition No. EN0773)
Censorship
Dear Chair

span.span: Petition requesting banning of Netflix series

p.span: Thank you for your letter of 18 February 2019 about petition EN0780 regarding the request from petitioners to ban the Netflix series, Chilling Adventures of Sabrina: Part 1 (the Series).

On 3 October 2018, the Series was classified MA 15+ (Mature Accompanied) with consumer advice of 'Strong horror themes, strong blood and gore, strong violence' by the Netflix Classification Tool (the Tool). The MA 15+ classification is considered unsuitable for persons under the age of 15 years. It is a legally restricted category. The Series was made available to Australia audiences by Netflix on 26 October 2018. To date, my Department has not received any complaints about the Series.

I have approved the use of the Tool to make classification decisions for films that are made available to Australian audiences via the Netflix streaming service. The Tool is able to make decisions that are broadly consistent with Australian community standards and decisions of the Classification Board (the Board). Decisions made by the Tool are deemed to be decisions of the Board.

Decisions of the Tool can be checked by the Board and if the Board decides that it would determine a different rating and/or different consumer advice, the decision of the Tool can be revoked and replaced with the new decision. The Board has checked the decision the Tool made for the Series and the Board determined the same MA 15+ rating as the Tool but determined slightly different consumer advice. The Board's consumer advice is 'strong horror themes and violence'; the Tool's consumer advice was 'Strong horror themes, strong blood and gore, strong violence'. I am advised that Netflix works closely with my Department and will change the decision on the service's Australian user interface to reflect the Board's consumer advice preference.

When making decisions, the Board applies the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 (the Act), the National Classification Code (the Code) and the Guidelines for the Classification of Films (the Guidelines), The Guidelines set out a hierarchy of impact from 'very mild' (G) to 'high' (R 18+). The consideration of impact and context are essential principles in the use of the Guidelines. The Act, the Code and the Guidelines are available on the Australian Classification website at

The Guidelines state that when classifying a film, the impact of six classifiable elements, Themes, Violence, Sex, Language, Drug Use and Nudity must be assessed and that context and impact must be taken into consideration.

Horror and supernatural elements in films are considered to be thematic elements. The Guidelines state that strong themes, if justified by context, can be accommodated at MA 15+. The Guidelines also state that 'there are virtually no restrictions on the treatment of themes at the R 18+ classification level, which means it is very unlikely that a film will be refused classification (banned) on the basis of themes alone. For a film to be banned for violent content, that violence must be gratuitous, exploitative or offensive and must have a very high degree of impact or be excessively frequent, prolonged or detailed. The Board determined that the violence in the Series was of a strong impact and the impact of the violence was 'mitigated by the fantastic nature and often light hearted tone of the film'.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information will be of assistance in responding to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator the Hon. Mitch Fifield(Petition No. EN0780)
Childcare Benefits
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 18 February 2019 regarding petition number EN0800 requesting that skilled migrant workers on temporary visas be eligible for Australian Government child care fee assistance.

For individuals to access Australian Government family assistance payments, including Child Care Subsidy, families must meet certain legislative eligibility requirements, including residency requirements. Unlike most other developed countries, Government programs and payments are funded from taxation revenue through residents, rather than direct contributions by individuals and employers. On this basis, individuals that meet Australian residency requirements are prioritised as the beneficiaries.

With the introduction of the new child care package from 2 July 2018, the Child Care Subsidy retains the previous eligibility requirements for child care fee assistance payments that does not extend eligibility to all skilled migrant workers that are temporary visa class holders.

To be eligible for the Child Care Subsidy, an individual or their partner must be an Australian resident or have a special category visa, or have a certain type of temporary visa. There are some exceptions to the residence requirements where an individual who is not an Australian resident may still be eligible for the Child Care Subsidy.

Skilled migrant workers who are uncertain of their eligibility for child care fee assistance and other family payments are encouraged to contact the Department of Human Services by calling 136 150 between 8.00 am and 8.00 pm Monday to Friday, or by going to their website at www.humanservices.gov.au/childcare, or by visiting one of their Service Centres.

More information on the residency requirements for the Child Care Subsidy is also available in the Guides to Social Policy Law, Family Assistance Guide online at http://guides.dss.gov.au/family-assistance-guide/2/1/2.
I trust this information is of assistance to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, the Hon. Dan Tehan MP(Petition No. EN0800)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Remedial Massage

p.span: Goods and Services Tax: Remedial Massage
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 February 2019, originally directed to the Treasurer, regarding petition EN0807, which concerned the removal of goods and services tax (GST) on services such as remedial massage and other soft tissue therapies. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me. The delay in response is regretted.

The GST applies broadly to goods and services with limited exemptions in areas such as food, education and certain health services. These limited GST exemptions for health services include those for which a Medicare benefit is payable and some specific services performed by a recognised health professional.

Providing GST concessions to a wider range of health-related goods and services could raise complex definitional issues, have the potential to create anomalies and lead to calls for further exemptions.

As the GST is collected by the Australian Government on behalf of the State and Territory governments, exempting a wider range of health services could also reduce the revenue available to the states and territories to fund essential services, such as schools and hospitals.

The Government believes Australians deserve a world class health system with affordable access to services provided by highly skilled doctors, nurses and health professionals. This system must be efficient and sustainable; keeping health costs affordable in the long term and ensuring taxpayer dollars are not wasted. In many cases, this can be most effectively achieved through direct payments and support programs rather than through further changes to the tax system.
I trust this information is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, the Hon. Stuart Robert MP(Petition No. EN0807)
Child Sexual Abuse
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 February 2019 concerning petition number EN0809 which calls for tougher penalties for convicted child sex offenders.
A key priority of the Australian Government is to prevent the abhorrent abuse and exploitation of children, and to ensure that offenders are sufficiently punished and deterred from future offending.

On 14 February 2019, I introduced the Combatting Child Sexual Exploitation Legislation Amendment Bill 2019 into the Parliament. This Bill seeks to strengthen the Commonwealth framework of offences by implementing key recommendations from the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse. It also addresses operational difficulties the Australian Federal Police, Australian Border Force and Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions are facing in investigating and prosecuting new trends in child exploitation.

To address the manifestly inadequate sentences being handed down to Commonwealth child sex offenders, Government has also introduced the Crimes Legislation Amendment (Sexual Crimes Against Children and Community Protection Measures) Bill 2017. This Bill seeks to increase the maximum penalties and introduce mandatory minimum sentences and a presumption in favour of an actual term of imprisonment for the most serious Commonwealth child sex offences. These measures will ensure the punishment adequately reflects the gravity of the crimes.
Both Bills are currently awaiting debate in the Parliament.

These proposed legislative reforms will enhance the Government's already robust efforts to protect children. These efforts include the proposal to establish a National Public Register of Child Sex Offenders and the ongoing operations of the Australian Centre to Combat Child Exploitation, which was established in August 2018.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
