Also, we desperately need our airport to be upgraded to give us long-range reach into the Asian region. This could deliver over 4,410 jobs and deliver $12.7 billion into our regional economy. There are so many terrific infrastructure and congestion-busting projects in the regions. This government just needs to start funding them.
The DEPUTY SPEAKER: The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
Aged Care
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) the latest Government report indicates more than 129,000 older Australians are waiting for their approved home care package;
(b) more than 75,000 older Australians on the waiting list have no home care package at all; and
(c) since 2017 the wait list for home care has grown from 88,000 to more than 129,000 older Australians;
(2) recognises:
(a) the majority of older Australians are waiting for level three and level four packages, who have high care needs;
(b) some older Australians have been waiting more than two years for their approved package; and
(c) older Australians are entering residential aged care or even emergency departments instead of receiving their approved home care package;
(3) condemns the Government for failing to stop the wait list growing; and
(4) calls on the Government to immediately fix the home care packages waiting list and properly address this growing crisis—

Ms SWANSON (Paterson) (19:22): It is said that a nation can be judged by the way it treats its young and its elderly. By this sentiment, this government should really be ashamed. The latest government report indicates that more than 129,000 older Australians are waiting for their already approved home care packages. I just want to say that figure one more time: in 2019 there are over 129,000 older Australians who have approved home care packages but who have not been provided with those packages. It really is a disgrace. Since 2017, the wait list for home care has grown from 88,000 to more than 129,000.

As lawmakers in this House, we have an absolute obligation to support our ageing population, and we know the bubble is just ahead of us. Our population is ageing, but we know that population bubble is coming down the road. Forget the Canberra bubble; we've got the ageing-population bubble coming, and we can't even cope with the demand on packages right now. This is seriously a policy void that the Morrison government must tackle.

Like so many others across the nation, the number of older Australians in my electorate who are waiting for the care they desperately need and deserve keeps getting higher and higher. My office regularly hears from constituents in absolutely heartbreaking situations, like the woman who had to pay hundreds of dollars for her husband to be in hospital because she couldn't care for him at home and his aged-care package hadn't been delivered despite waiting months. It's not uncommon to hear about people who know they're eligible for a level 3 or 4 package but who apply for a level 2 because they know they'll probably get that quicker than the one they desperately need. If ever there was a requirement for a massive shakeup, it's aged care in Australia.

Older Australians in my community are entering residential aged care, and even more, emergency departments, instead of receiving their approved home care package—so much for growing old in your own home in safety and dignity. When we talk about the number of people who are waiting for care, it's important to take a step back and think about the lives behind those numbers. Earlier this month, I met some extraordinary Australians in our community, and I took part in Meals on Wheels. I hadn't done that for many, many years, but I went along with Beresfield Community Care to deliver the Friday Meals on Wheels. It was an incredible experience and I encourage all elected representatives to do some Meals on Wheels in their community. You get to go into the homes and meet older Australians, some of whom have worked hard and paid their taxes and are now doing it pretty tough. They really look forward to those meals. Not only that, it can be a very lonely existence for many of them. But they get up and they're there waiting for Meals on Wheels. It was truly a terrific opportunity for me to talk to people about their lives and just how they're feeling as they age in their homes. Whilst services like cleaning, making the bed and running the vacuum are great—and they are provided—I believe some of the big maintenance issues for people who are ageing in their own homes also need to be tackled. People are living in their family home but maintaining the home, and not just having it cleaned, is a real issue.

I want to touch briefly on Mary Frances Brennan. Last December I spoke about Mary, who had been waiting 530 days for her home care package. She was in and out of hospital with what her son John described as preventable illnesses, such as infections. In December, Mary was told it would take at least another six months for her to receive her package. When I first mentioned Mary, I said it was heartbreaking. Well, it's even more heartbreaking now because I stand here today to tell you that seven months after that speech Mary Frances Brennan passed away, having never received the aged care package she had applied for two years and 20 days earlier. Mary's son John and her husband, Peter, acknowledged that her home care package may not have prolonged her life, but they know that it would have made her quality of life so much better. Truly, where are we in Australia in 2019 when people are dying for the help they deserve and desperately need?

Dr MARTIN (Reid) (19:27): I rise today to commend the progress that has been made by the government since 2013 to increase the number of home care packages made available to older Australians. There would be few people in this place who have not been personally affected by the challenges of caring for an older family member, whether it be a parent, a grandparent, or a member of the extended family. Indeed, my own mother and her siblings are currently caring for their mother, my 92-year-old grandmother, who chooses to stay in her own home.

Home care packages allow older Australians to make the choice to stay in their homes for longer. This is an important choice. It allows more people to approach their later stages of life with greater dignity and independence. It also eases the workload often shouldered by family members who take up the role of caring for older Australians in addition to working full time and supporting their own children. Since 2012 and 2013, the government has increased the number of home care packages from just over 60,000 to over 124,000 in 2018-19, with more than 157,000 projected by 2022-23. This year, a further 10,000 home care packages will be available across all four levels of care.

The Morrison government has also extended the Commonwealth Home Support Program for a further two years, providing continuity of service for 800,000 consumers. Just last week, a further $150 million over three years was granted and announced by Minister Colbeck for providers of the Commonwealth Home Support Program. It is for entry-level care, to expand the program in areas where demand currently outstrips supply.

This is in stark contrast to Labor who, at the election, went to the polls with no additional funding for home care packages or aged care more broadly. When Labor left office in 2013, funding for aged care was $13.3 billion. Under our government, funding for aged care will continue to grow to $25.4 billion in 2023. With an ageing population, there is significant pressure on the aged-care industry to grow and adapt to meet market demands. More Australians than ever before are seeking support through home care or residential aged care, and I am pleased that the Morrison government is taking steps to secure this support into the future.

I want to acknowledge, briefly, the work of the multicultural organisations in my electorate of Reid in supporting the needs of older Australians from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds. Firstly, there is the work of the Chinese Australian Services Society, CASS, led by Dr Bo Zhou. CASS provides support to a broad range of people, particularly the East Asian communities in Sydney. Today I'd like to congratulate them on the home care packages and Commonwealth home support programs they deliver with the culturally appropriate services they provide.

CASS also supports older Australians with aged-care centres. I was particularly interested in their integration of the program with early learning and childcare day care centres, which benefits both children and older Australians. The interactions between both ends of the life span—young people in day care but also the aged care—was very interesting to observe, and I understand Griffith University is conducting a research study on this very model.

Last year, Minister Wyatt, who was then the Minister for Aged Care, visited Reid to open the Gallipoli Home aged-care facility in Auburn. It is the first aged-care facility dedicated to providing care for Muslim and culturally diverse seniors. I'm pleased the federal government was able to provide $10 million to bring this project to fruition, in recognition of the growing number of older Australians born overseas. Home care packages are an important part of the support available for older Australians who choose to remain in their homes longer, like my 92-year-old grandmother. The services— (Time expired)

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Hogan ): The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
QUESTIONS IN WRITING
Sinosteel
(Question No. 1)

Mr Katter To ask the Treasurer—(1) Is it a fact, as referred to by Mr Clive Palmer in the election campaign, that the Chinese company Sinosteel (which is waiting for approval from the Foreign Investment Review Board to buy a significant proportion of Australia's iron ore reserves) will receive a major airport, rail line and deep-water shipping port as part of the pending sales agreement.(2) Can the Treasurer confirm that this Sinosteel is the same Sinosteel that is operating in Zimbabwe.(3) Is the Treasurer aware of the claim, inter alia, rightly or wrongly, that thousands of Chinese prisoners have been taken to Zimbabwe to work in mining and/or other jobs for negligible wages precluding any significant benefit accruing to Zimbabwe.(4) If there is substance to these and/or other allegations relating to Chinese mining and or Sinosteel, can he give surety that the project will not be approved by the Australian Government.(5) As a competing tenderer for this project is apparently a corporation that includes a Queensland Government's (Treasury) 'superannuation corporate entity' and therefore is not only owned by an Australian company but owned by a significant number of the Australian people, should this not in itself preclude a foreign tenderer.(6) Given that 83 per cent of our mineral resources are already foreign owned, will the Treasurer put a stop to Sinosteel's pending purchase.
Mr Frydenberg: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Government does not comment on the application of the foreign investment framework as it applies or could apply to particular cases due to strict confidentiality and privacy law requirements.

More broadly, foreign investment proposals are assessed by the Foreign Investment Review Board to ensure they are not contrary to Australia's national interest. The national interest assessment includes a range of factors such as national security, competition, the impact on the economy and the character of the investor. Under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975, the Treasurer can block proposals found to be contrary to the national interest, or can impose conditions on an investment to address national interest concerns.
Infrastructure
(Question No. 2)
Ms Sharkie asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, in writing, on 3 July 2019:

In respect of the $5 million promised during the 2019 federal election campaign and announced on 5 May 2019, to provide for overtaking lanes on Long Valley Road, in South Australia: (a) when will the money be released; and (b) when will the project (i) commence, and (ii) be completed.
Mr McCormack: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Australian Government has committed $5 million to deliver the Long Valley Road upgrade between Mount Barker and Strathalbyn and is working with the South Australian Government to progress the delivery of this project. Planning and design is expected to commence by mid 2020 and these planning works will determine the construction timeframes. The Australian Government funding will be released via milestone payments.
The Government is continuing to work with the SA Government to progress delivery of this project and to accelerate progress wherever possible.
Murray-Darling Basin
(Question No. 3)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

1. In respect of the $308,000 from the Murray-Darling Basin Economic Development Program announced in March 2019 to restore the historic Lakeside Butter Factory in Milang, South Australia: (a) has the money been released to the grant recipient; if not, why not and when will the funding be released; and
(b) when will the project be completed.
Mr Littleproud: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(a) No money has been released yet for this project to the Milang and District Community Association Incorporated (the Association). The Association requested the department delay negotiations on the funding agreement until they were ready to engage on the details of the project. The department is making regular contact with the Association and hopes to commence discussions soon. The funds will be released under milestone payment arrangements when a funding agreement is in place.
(b) A completion date will be agreed with the Association as part of the funding agreement.
Murray-Darling Basin
(Question No. 4)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

In respect of the $247,580 from the Murray-Darling Basin Economic Development Program announced prior to the 2019 federal election to enhance and increase nature-based tourism, visitation and recreation to boost economic activity in the River Murray Lower Lakes region through improved public access, facilities and ecological health:
(a) Has the money been released to the grant recipient; if not, why not and when will the funding be released; and
(b) When will the project be completed.
Mr Littleproud: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(a) No money has been released yet for this project to Goolwa to Wellington Local Action Planning Association Incorporated (the Association). The department is in the final stages of negotiations with the Association over its funding agreement. The funds will be released under milestone payment arrangements when a funding agreement is in place.
(b) The Association has proposed a project end date in August 2020.
Infrastructure
(Question No. 5)
Ms Sharkie asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, in writing, on 3 July 2019:

1) Will the 'South Eastern Freeway Managed Motorways' project to upgrade the South Eastern Freeway between the towns of Crafters and Stirling in South Australia, which the Minister stated during question time on 5 December 2018 that he expected would commence and be completed in 2019, actually be completed in 2019.

2) If the project is to be completed in 2019, why does the South Australian Government's Department of Planning, Transport and Infrastructure document ' Forward Work Plan: Major Programs 2022 ' show that construction of this project will not commence until the third quarter of the 2020-21 financial year, more than eighteen months away.
3) Has the Australian Government released the promised $4.5 million in funding as its share for this project; if not, why not.
4) When will the project: (a) commence; and (b) be completed.
Mr McCormack: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Australian Government has committed $7.1 million to deliver the South Eastern Freeway Managed Motorways project. The South Australian Government has advised that due to complications in the detailed design phase, construction has been delayed and is now expected to commence in late 2019. Australian Government funding of $150,000 has been provided for the development stage of this project and future funding will be released via milestone payments on a needs basis as negotiated with the South Australian Government.
Infrastructure
(Question No. 6)
Ms Sharkie asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, in writing, on 3 July 2019:

In respect of the $73.6 million promised prior to the 2019 federal election campaign and announced on 2 April 2019, to duplicate Victor Harbor Road between Main South Road and McLaren Vale in South Australia: (a) will the funding be released during the current term of this Government; if not, why not and when will those funds be released; and (b) when will the project (i) commence, and (ii) be completed.
Mr McCormack: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Australian Government has committed $73.6 million to deliver the duplication of Victor Harbor Road between Main South Road and McLaren Vale and is working with the South Australian Government to progress the delivery of this project. The South Australian Government has advised that this project may commence in 2021 and be completed in 2022. The Australian Government funding will be released via milestone payments which are yet to be negotiated with the South Australian Government.
The Government is continuing to work with the SA Government to progress delivery of this project and to accelerate progress wherever possible.
Infrastructure
(Question No. 7)
Ms Sharkie asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, in writing, on 3 July 2019:

In respect of the $2 million promised during the 2019 federal election campaign and announced on 8 May 2019, to upgrade the intersections of Onkaparinga Valley Road and Tiers and Nairne roads in Woodside, South Australia: (a) when will the funds be released; and (b) when will the project (i) commence, and (ii) be completed.
Mr McCormack: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Australian Government has committed $2 million to deliver the Onkaparinga Valley Road‑Tiers Road-Nairne Road intersection upgrade at Woodside and is working with the South Australian Government to progress the delivery of this project. Planning and design is expected to commence by early 2020 and these planning works will determine the construction timeframes. The Australian Government funding will be released via milestone payments.
The Government is continuing to work with the SA Government to progress delivery of this project and to accelerate progress wherever possible.
Infrastructure
(Question No. 9)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister representing the Minister for Youth and Sport, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

In respect of the nearly $500,000 from the Government's Community Sport Infrastructure grant program promised to upgrade and improve the change rooms at Heathfield Oval in Heathfield, South Australia: (a) have the funds been released to the grant recipient; if not, why not and when will the funding be released; and (b) when will the project be completed.

span.span: The Minister for Youth and Sport has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question

p.span: a) The funding agreement to support delivery of this project was sent to Adelaide Hills Council in late June 2019 and is yet to be returned by Adelaide Hills Council. Once the agreement is received, Sport Australia will finalise the agreement and provide the funding to the organisation.
b) This project is scheduled to be completed by 31 August 2020.
Environment
(Question No. 10)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for the Environment, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

In respect of the $1.5 million promised from the Environment Restoration Fund during the 2019 federal election campaign to recover at-risk species, specifically the Kangaroo Island's endangered dunnart: (a) when will those funds be released; and (b) when will the project (i) commence, and (ii) be completed.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

In response to Ms Sharkie's question, on 03 July 2019. The Australian Government remains committed to the recovery of our at-risk species, with $1.5 million to be invested for Kangaroo Island's threatened Dunnart under the Environment Restoration Fund.

The Department of the Environment and Energy is working with Natural Resources Kangaroo Island to deliver this project. It is anticipated that onground recovery efforts will commence from October 2019. The project will run for four years, with funding to be provided each year of the project until June 2023.
Refugees
(Question No. 11)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in writing, on 3 July 2019:

(1) Under international law, do Australia and Nauru share joint responsibility for ensuring that the human rights of children and adults subject to third country processing are adequately protected; if not, why not.(2) Is access to healthcare a basic human right, regardless of immigration status; if not, why not.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

(1) Australia takes its international obligations seriously. Australia maintains its international obligations are not extra-territorial, and that Nauru assumes responsibility for all individuals under its jurisdiction. To this end, through the Memorandum of Understanding with Australia, Nauru has committed to treat transferees with dignity and respect, and in accordance with relevant human rights standards.

(2) Regional processing arrangements in Nauru, including healthcare arrangements, are the responsibility of the Government of Nauru. The Australian Government supports the Government of Nauru to implement regional processing arrangements by contracting specialist healthcare and welfare services to support the needs of refugees and asylum seekers residing in Nauru. Processes are in place to support medical transfers to a third country where essential health and medical treatment is unavailable in a regional processing country.
Aged Care
(Question No. 12)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians, in writing, on 03 July 2019:
(1) Is it a fact that the national package queue for home care packages grew from 88,000 in June 2017 to 108,000 in March 2018, to 121,000 in June 2018 and to 128,000 in December 2018.

(2) What number of the approximately 128,000 people waiting to receive their approved level of home care packages resides in the electoral division of Mayo, and of these, how many (a) have been approved for Level 1, 2, 3 and 4 packages, and (b) are on an interim home care package and awaiting their approved package level.
(3) What is the average wait time for the receipt of approved levels of home care package applications in (a) Australia, and (b) the electoral division of Mayo.
Mr Hunt: The Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Yes
(2) The Department of Health (the Department) does not collect this information at electoral division level.

(3) At a national level, for those people who were assigned a home care package in 2017-18, the following table provides the median time in months that had elapsed since those people were approved for a home care package.
Package Level
Median

The Department does not break down data on elapsed wait times beyond the national level as this would involve a significant diversion of resources. Irrespective of this, the NPS ensures home care packages are assigned in a consistent and equitable way based on a person's individual needs and circumstances, regardless of where they live in Australia. As such, any variation in actual wait times between states and territories or ACPRs would be negligible.
Anti-Siphoning List
(Question No. 13)

Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts—(1) In light of the community backlash at Cricket Australia's deal with Foxtel/Channel Seven to screen one day international cricket matches on pay TV, will the Minister review the effectiveness of the Broadcasting Services (Events) Notice, otherwise known as the anti-siphoning list, as a means to allow free-to-air broadcasters first right to negotiate on major sporting events of significant national interest; if not, why not.(2) Will the Government consider any other legislative instruments to allow Australians to watch significant national events on free-to-air broadcasts; if not, why not.
Mr Fletcher: The answer to the member's question is as follows:

"The rules relating to sport broadcast rights are included in what is known as the 'anti-siphoning scheme'. The anti-siphoning scheme is established by the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 and ensures that free-to-air broadcasters have the first opportunity to acquire rights to events on the anti-siphoning list. The anti-siphoning scheme is the extent of the Australian Government's involvement in the negotiation for sport broadcast rights. These rights are held by individual sporting organisations and it is the responsibility of such organisations to achieve a proper balance between pursuing commercial opportunities from the sale of their rights and their broader responsibilities as stewards of their respective sports for the benefit of all fans and participants. The negotiation of sports broadcast rights are largely commercial decisions for the parties involved. The Government does not seek to intervene excessively in such matters.

The Government will continue to monitor the anti-siphoning scheme to ensure there are policy settings in place which appropriately balance the legitimate commercial interests of sporting organisations and broadcasters with the interests of Australian audiences."
Murray-Darling Basin
(Question No. 15)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management, in writing, on 03 July 2019:
1. What total sum of funding did the Government expend on water research in:

and of this, what proportion was expended on the Murray-Darling Basin, including the (i) names of the agencies conducting the research, (ii) proportion received by each, and (iii) exact purpose for which the funding was granted.
2 What total sum of funding has the Government allocated to water research in 2019-20, and of this, what proportion will be expended on the Murray-Darling Basin, including the:
a. names of the agencies conducting the research.
b. proportion received by each
c. exact purpose for which the funding has been granted.
Mr Littleproud: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
1. Water research has been interpreted to include research activities associated with inland waterways, wetlands and catchments but does not include oceanic or marine water research.

Australian Government funded water research activities are undertaken and funded by a range of agencies across a number of portfolios. Funding for water research activities is provided through grants programs; partnerships with the private sector, universities, and state and territory governments; and within normal operations of Australian Government research organisations. Note that CSIRO reported it is not possible to quantify the number of projects or funding associated with 'water research' in CSIRO because CSIRO does not classify its research using this definition. CSIRO's response is at Attachment A.

The total sum of funding the Australian Government expended on water research and the proportion expended in the Murray-Darling Basin between 2015-16 and 2018-19 is set out in Table 1 below. Note that due to differences in how different Australian Government agencies define, classify and report funding on water research, the figures should be treated as estimates based on best available data.
(i) The names of the agencies conducting the research is set out in Table 2 below.
(ii) The proportion of funding received by each agency is set out in Table 2 below.

(iii) The purpose for which the funding was granted to specific water research by agency is detailed in Attachment B. Note that where CSIRO is involved in a project, this information has been included by the lead agency on the project rather than by CSIRO.

p.span: Visas
(Question No. 16)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

(1) Why has the Government sought to privatise visa services.(2) What national security assessments have been undertaken regarding the decision to issue the Request for Tender (RFT) Delivering Visa Services for Australia—Global Digital Platform.(3) Has the Government identified any national security concerns with privatising visa services as a result of those assessments.(4) Is this RFT a 'limited' tender; if so, (a) why, (b) what are the requirements of this limited tender, and (c) does the RFT adhere to these requirements.(5) Is it a fact that two prospective tenderers have so far publicly put up their hand for the visa contract, as reported by Paul Karp in a recent media article 'Labor threatens to abandon Coalition's $1bn deal to privatise visa processing' (The Guardian, 19 February 2019).(6) Is it possible that the Government could sign a contract before October 2019, and can he indicate if that is the Government's intention.(7) Does the current RFT timeline indicate that Phase One of the tender closed on 20 February and allows for the possibility that the Government will not pursue the second stage of the tender.(8) If the Government decides Phase Two is unnecessary, what would be the indicative timeline for contract signing and service delivery.(9) Will the Government be including standard Freedom of Information clauses in the final contract awarded under the RFT process.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
(1) The Government is not privatising Australia's visa system or decision making.

(2) The agencies of Government and the functional areas of my Department responsible for national security and critical infrastructure have been involved in the planning of this procurement and continue to be engaged throughout the process.

(3) The RFT documentation identifies the Government's intent to impose strict controls and safeguards in relation to national security, foreign ownership and access, and management control to protect the Commonwealth's interests.
(4) No, it is a multi-stage procurement with an open approach to the market at the Request for Expression of Interest (REOI) stage. REOI 22/17-B1 was issued in September 2017.
(5) See Part 1 RFT details for an overview of the procurement process.
(6) See Part 1 RFT details for an overview of the procurement process.
(7) Yes.
(8) In accordance with the RFT, entering into contract was not an available option at the end of Phase One.
(9) Yes, in the event that an outcome is reached.
Environment
(Question No. 17)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for the Environment, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

Does Australia currently have a proposal for a marine park in the East Antarctic before the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Living Marine Resources (CCAMLR); if so: (a) how large would that park be in relation to other marine parks worldwide, and what important flora and fauna would it protect; (b) what is the history of the park proposal; (c) what is the remaining CCAMLR process for approval of the park; and (d) what priority does Australia place on the park proposal, and how important is it for the park to be put in place as soon as possible.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Yes. Australia along with the EU and its Member States are intending to submit the proposal for a marine protected area (MPA) in the East Antarctic to the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) for consideration during the 38th CCAMLR Meeting (2019).
(a) The proposal, as presented to CCAMLR in 2018, contains three areas comprising approximately 1 million square kilometres in East Antarctica.
There are over 15,000 MPAs globally, but only two MPAs in the CCAMLR area:
Ross Sea Marine Protected Area, the world's largest marine protected area, which is 1.55 million square kilometres.
South Orkney Islands Southern Shelf Marine Protected Area, which is
94,000 square kilometres.

The East Antarctic Marine Protected Area proposal seeks to protect areas important to ecosystem processes, such as feeding areas for marine mammals, penguins and other seabirds. It also seeks to include reference areas for understanding the effects of fishing and impacts of climate change.
(b) The proposal has been considered by CCAMLR every year since 2012, and while it has received wide support from Members, it has not successfully achieved consensus.
(c) All decisions of CCAMLR are by consensus so all Members must agree to the proposal. It is not unexpected for a proposal of this significance to take time.

(d) Australia is a strong supporter of a representative system of marine protected areas in Antarctica, and in particular the East Antarctic Marine Protected Area proposal. Australia is actively working with CCAMLR Members to achieve consensus for the proposal and have the MPA implemented as soon as possible.
Criminal Responsibility
(Question No. 18)
Ms Sharkie asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

To ask the Attorney-General—In respect of the review into increasing the age of criminal responsibility announced by the Attorney-General at the Council of Attorneys General meeting in November 2018: (a) when will the review be completed; and (b) which agency, taskforce or individual will undertake the review..
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(a) On 23 November 2018, the Council of Attorneys-General agreed to establish a working group to examine whether it would be appropriate to raise the minimum age of criminal responsibility in Australia, drawing from relevant jurisdictional and international experience. The working group is expected to report back within 12 months from its establishment. The full text of the meeting communique is available at:
https://www.ag.gov.au/About/CommitteesandCouncils/Council-of-Attorneys-General/Documents/Council-of-Attorneys-General-communique-November-2018.pdf
(b) The working group is chaired by Western Australia and consists of representatives from all States and Territories and the Commonwealth.
Criminal Responsibility
(Question No. 19)
Ms Sharkie asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

To ask the Attorney-General—In respect of the Council of Attorneys General review into the age of criminal responsibility announced in November 2018, will the Government take into consideration the findings and recommendations of the Report of the Royal Commission and Board of Inquiry Into the Protection and Detention of Children in the Northern Territory, including but not limited to Recommendation 27.1 which provided for the age of criminal responsibility to be increased to 12 years.
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

On 23 November 2018, the Council of Attorneys-General agreed to establish a working group to examine whether it would be appropriate to raise the minimum age of criminal responsibility in Australia, drawing from relevant jurisdictional and international experience. The working group includes representatives from every Australian jurisdiction and is chaired by Western Australia.

It is expected the working group will take into account a range of government and non‑government reports, international reviews, inquiries and evidence-based research, including the findings and recommendations of the Report of the Royal Commission and Board of Inquiry Into the Protection and Detention of Children in the Northern Territory.
Criminal Responsibility
(Question No. 20)
Ms Sharkie asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

To ask the Attorney-General—In respect of the Council of Attorneys General review into the age of criminal responsibility announced in November 2018, will the Government take into consideration the following comments and recommendations of the United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child: (a) General Comment No. 10 (2007), and in particular, the Committee's recommendation that 'States parties are encouraged to increase their lower MACR [minimum age of criminal responsibility] to the age of 12 years as the absolute minimum age and to continue to increase it to a higher age level'; and (b) Draft General Comment No. 24 (201x), replacing General Comment No. 10 (2007), released in January 2019, and in particular, the Committee's recommendation that '…the Committee had considered 12 years as the absolute minimum age. However, the Committee finds that this age indication is still low. States parties are encouraged to increase their minimum age to at least 14 years of age'.
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

On 23 November 2018, the Council of Attorneys-General agreed to establish a working group to examine whether it would be appropriate to raise the minimum age of criminal responsibility in Australia, drawing from relevant jurisdictional and international experience.

The working group includes representatives from every Australian jurisdiction and is chaired by Western Australia. It is expected the working group will take into account a range of government and non‑government reports, international reviews, inquiries and evidence-based research, including the views of the United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child.
Youth Justice
(Question No. 21)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister representing the Minister for Youth and Sport, in writing, on 03 July 2019:
(1) For each state and territory, and between: (a) 1 January and 31 December 2016;

(b) 1 January and 31 December 2017; (c) 1 January and 31 December 2018; and (d) 1 January and 30 June 2019, (i) how many children were detained in a youth justice centre or detention facility, (ii) what is the breakdown of male and female children, and (iii) how many children were in detention while on remand.
(2) In respect of (1) (i) and (iii) above, what proportion (as a percentage) of children identify as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander.
(3) For each state and territory, what proportion (as a percentage) of the current female and male adult prison population, were detained as children.
Mr Hunt: The Minister for Youth and Sport has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

The requested information, and more, is publicly available from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare website by visiting the link https://www.aihw.gov.au/reports-data and searching "Youth Justice".
Integrated Carer Support Service
(Question No. 22)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister representing the Minister for Families and Social Services in writing on 3 July 2019:

(1)How does the Government intend to implement the Integrated Carer Support Service (ICSS) online service delivery model, in areas with poor and unreliable internet and telephone services.(2)What funding has been allocated to each state and territory within the ICSS to provide planned respite funding for carers, other than consumer directed financial packages each capped at $3,000.(3)What total sum of funding was available to organisations through the Department of Social Services recent grant funding round to establish a network of Regional Delivery Partners (RDPs) across Australia, and what was the allocation for each state and territory.(4)Of the $168.87 million allocated to departmental funded carer services in 2017-18 what was the allocation for each state and territory.(5)What were the total funds allocated to departmental funded carer services in 2018-19 and what was the allocation for each state and territory.(6)How many RDPs are in each state and territory, and what factors determined how RDPs were allocated to each state and territory.(7)Noting previous delays to the implementation of the ICSS, when will RDPs commence providing services to the community.(8)Does the Government intend to conduct a review within two years of the implementation of the ICSS; if so, has the Government collected sufficient baseline data to enable a meaningful consideration of the effectiveness of the program.
Mr Fletcher: The Minister for Families and Social Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

1. The Integrated Carer Support Service (ICSS) model offers carers living in regional and remote areas multiple options to access support services. The new online carer services are just one way to obtain support. Carers will be able to access in-person supports, as in the current service system, through their local Carer Gateway Regional Delivery Partner (RDP) when established.

2. Each RDP will be allocated a pool of funding to provide a full suite of services including carer support planning, in-person coaching, counselling and peer support, emergency and short term respite. RDPs will allocate and deliver these services flexibly (including emergency and planned respite) according to demand for each service type in their service region.
3. The total amount of funding for the Carer Gateway RDP grant agreements over five years (2019-20 to 2023-24) is $493.28 million. The allocation is:
Australian Capital Territory - $8.66 million
New South Wales - $159.28 million
Victoria - $102.43 million
Queensland - $97.95 million
Tasmania - $22.08 million
South Australia - $47.88 million
Northern Territory - $9.11 million
Western Australia - $45.89 million.
4. The requested breakdown is not available. Funding was not allocated on a state and territory basis.

5. In 2018-19, the total amount of funds allocated to departmental carer services was $200.7 million. This figure comprises $149.8 million for current carer programs, $32.1 million for carer programs transitioning to the National Disability Insurance Scheme and $18.8 million for the Integrated Carer Support Service. The requested breakdown by state and territory is not available. Funding is not allocated on a state and territory basis.

6. There will be 16 RDPs nationally: one in the Australian Capital Territory, four in New South Wales, three in Queensland, two in Victoria, one in Tasmania, two in South Australia, one in the Northern Territory and two in Western Australia. Information on how the Carer Gateway service areas were developed is available at www.dss.gov.au/disability-and-carers-carers-icss-implementation/carer-gateway-service-areas.

7. The first phase commenced in July 2019 with the introduction of new online services through the Carer Gateway website. The RDPs will commence establishment and service delivery in late 2019, with current carer service providers funded to May 2020 to deliver continuity of carer supports.

8. The Department of Social Services collects a range of data on carers. However, the implementation of the ICSS model will provide the department with the opportunity, for the first time, to establish a carer service data set that is nationally consistent. Evaluation activities for the ICSS program, including effectiveness, will commence in 2019-20.
Agriculture
(Question No. 25)

Ms Sharkie To ask the Ministers listed below (question Nos. *25 to *26)—(1)Does netting for crops, especially permanent netting for horticultural crops, protect against droughts and high temperatures; if so, to what extent.(2)In respect of the explanatory memorandum to the Tax Laws Amendment (Small Business Measures No. 2) Bill 2015 (page 33), has the Government considered extending accelerated depreciation to netting for primary producers; if so, what was concluded; if not, why not.(3)How, and to what extent, has the Government made the Future Drought Fund accessible to the horticulture industry.
Mr Sukkar: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1)Refer to Question 26.(2)The instant asset write-off enables small and medium-sized businesses, including primary producers, that have an aggregated annual turnover of less than $50 million to immediately deduct purchases of eligible assets each costing less than $30,000, until 30 June 2020. Horticultural crop netting is an eligible asset under the Government's instant asset write‑off.
(3)Refer to Question 26.
Agriculture
(Question No. 26)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management, in writing, on 03 July 2019:
1. Does netting for crops, especially permanent netting for horticultural crops, protect against droughts and high temperatures; if so, to what extent.

2. In respect of the explanatory memorandum to the Tax Laws Amendment (Small Business Measures No. 2) Bill 2015 (page 33), has the Government considered extending accelerated depreciation to netting for primary producers; if so, what was concluded; if not, why not.
3. How, and to what extent, has the Government made the Future Drought Fund accessible to the horticulture industry?
Mr Littleproud The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

1. As horticultural netting is not a fully enclosed horticultural production system where heating and cooling can be controlled, netting does not provide complete protection against drought and high temperatures.

A 2015 report prepared by Natural Logic and Econsearch on behalf of the Apple and Pear Growers Association of South Australia, noted water savings of between 15-45% and temperature decreases of between 1-3 degrees on warm days and between 3-6 degrees on hot days for orchards under netting.
2. A response to this question will be provided by the Treasury Department under Question on Notice 25.

3. The Future Drought Fund will provide a secure and continuous revenue stream to be used for drought resilience, preparedness and recovery to help farmers and communities prepare for inevitable future droughts. Work will soon commence on developing a Drought Resilience Funding Plan – a high level framework to guide the approach for supporting future projects. This process includes a six week period of public consultation.

The Future Drought Fund Consultative Committee will advise the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management about the Funding Plan. Members of the horticulture industry can help shape the Funding Plan by registering for the upcoming consultation at: haveyoursay.agriculture.gov.au/register.
Regional Investment Corporation
(Question No. 27)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management, in writing, on 03 July 2019:
1. As a result of hailstorms in 2018:

b. of these applications, how many, (i) have been approved, (ii) have been rejected, and (iii) are still awaiting determination.
2. What is the:
a. minimum
b. maximum
c. average, processing time for applications for RIC loans.
3. What is the reason for the current average processing time.
4. What steps is the Government taking to expedite the processing time.
Mr Littleproud: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

1. The RIC advised it has received less than 10 applications from the Adelaide Hills region in South Australia. The RIC does not report details where loan applications total less than ten (10) in order to maintain the privacy of its customers.
2. Processing times for the 2018–19 financial year are outlined below.

Note that reported figures represent the number of RIC processing days from receiving a complete application to making a decision on the application. Figures do not include days when the application is referred back to the applicant for further information.

3. The RIC advised that two issues contributed to initial delays in processing farm business loan applications—the early receipt of an unanticipated large volume of applications, and an initial shortfall in resourcing to meet that high level of demand.

4. The RIC has advised that both issues contributing to the initial delays have been addressed. The RIC has increased its team, improved its processes and continues to make improvements to the customer experience without compromising the integrity of the analysis required for loans of this size. Both factors have contributed to a significant improvement in application processing times, with the average processing time reducing from 72 days to 40 days in the May 2019 to June 2019 period.

Economy
(Question No. 28)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister representing the Minister for Families and Social Services in writing on 3 July 2019:

(1)To what extent does the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cash rate determine the Minister's setting of deeming rates.(2)Has the Minister received formal advice from the Department of Social Services or the Department of Human Services on deeming rates since the RBA last changed the cash rate; if so, what was that advice; if not, why not.(3)Further to the answer to question in writing No. 667, from the 45th Parliament, (House Hansard , 9 May 2017, pages 4085-6), will the Minister make a decision in September 2019 to alter or maintain the deeming rate.
Mr Fletcher: has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Available returns from savings accounts, term deposits and market-linked investments, including shares and superannuation, are considered when setting the deeming rates.
(2) I have received advice from my department on deeming since the RBA decision on the official cash rate. This is confidential advice to government.

(3) I announced my decision on 14 July 2019 to reduce the lower deeming rate to 1 per cent from 1.75 per cent, and the upper deeming rate to 3 per cent from 3.25 per cent. This change will be backdated to come into effect from 1 July 2019. Recipients affected by the deeming rules will receive the benefit from this change by the end of September.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Consumer Law Review: Final Report (Question No. 29)

p.span: Australian Consumer Law Review: Final Report
(Question No. 29)

Ms Sharkie to ask the Assistant Treasurer—(1)In respect of the Australian Consumer Law Review: Final Report , does the Government support Proposal 6 of the report.(2)Does the Government support the position of the Australian Competition and Consumer Competition to identify the development of a general safety provision as a product safety priority for 2019.(3)When will the Government release the regulatory impact statement for a proposed legislative amendment to include a general safety provision.
Mr Sukkar: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) At the 2017 Meeting of the Legislative and Governance Forum on Consumer Affairs (CAF), Ministers, including the Hon Michael McCormack MP, the then Commonwealth Minister for Small Business, asked officials to undertake a public regulatory impact assessment, with a focus on further consultation on the proposal to introduce a General Safety Provision into the Australian Consumer Law, including design and implementation issues.
(2) The Government notes the ACCC as an independent statutory authority has identified progressing the development of a General Safety Provision as one of nine product safety priorities for 2019.

(3) Consistent with the request from Ministers at the 2017 CAF Meeting, Consumer Affairs Australia and New Zealand (CAANZ) is currently developing a Consultation Regulatory Impact Statement (CRIS) on options to strengthen the product safety framework in the ACL.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Government Register of Lobbyists (Question No. 30)

p.span: Australian Government Register of Lobbyists
(Question No. 30)

Ms Sharkie To ask the Attorney-General —(1) How many individuals, companies and organisations have been registered on the Register of Lobbyists since it was established in 2008.(2) In respect of the Lobbying Code of Conduct, for the following periods: (a) since the register was established; (b) during the term of each Prime Minister since the register was established; and (c) between 18 May 2018 and 18 May 2019, (i) how many reports have been made of suspected or alleged breaches of the code, (ii) how many confirmed breaches of the code have occurred, and (iii) how many individuals, companies or organisations have been re-registered as a consequence of a breach of the code.(3) Where can members of the public locate information on which individual, company or organisation that have breached the code of conduct, and the consequences of the breach.
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) As of 8 August 2019, there are 266 entities and 836 individuals registered on the Australian Government Register of Lobbyists (the Register).

(2) Responsibility for the Australian Government Lobbying Code of Conduct (the Code) and the Register transferred from the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&C) to the Attorney-General's Department (AGD) on 10 May 2019.
Since the transfer of responsibility for the Code to AGD there have been no reports of suspected breaches of the Code.

(3) Members of the public can find out more about the Code and view the Register online at www.transparency.ag.gov.au. As per section 10.3 of the Code, any person that is found to have breached the Code will not appear on the Register. Allegations of non-compliance with the Code can be made via the website or by contacting the department on (02) 6141 2666 or lobbyistsregister@ag.gov.au.

Ms Sharkie To ask the Prime Minister—(1) How many lobbyists are currently registered on the Register of Lobbyists.(2) How many individuals currently possess a Parliament House, sponsored security pass (informally known as an orange pass), and what are the eligibility requirements for that pass..
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) As of 8 August 2019, there are 266 entities and 836 individual lobbyists registered on the Australian Government Register of Lobbyists.
(2) The Department of Parliamentary Services has responsibility for sponsored security pass access to Parliament House.
Aged Care
(Question No. 32)
Mrs Elliot asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

(1) Is it a fact that the waiting list for home care packages for older Australians across Australia has grown from 88,000 in June 2017 to more than 129,000 as at 31 March 2019.(2) What number of the approximate 129,000 people waiting to receive their approved level of home care packages reside in the electoral division of Richmond, and of these, how many: (a) have been approved for Level 1, 2, 3 and 4 packages; and (b) are on an interim home care package and awaiting their approved package level.(3) What is the average wait time for the receipt of approved levels of home care package applications in: (a) Australia; and (b) the electoral division of Richmond.
Mr Hunt: The Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
Answer:
(1) Yes.
(2) The Department of Health (the Department) does not collect this information at electoral division level.

(3) The Department does not break down data on elapsed wait times beyond the national level. The most recent published wait times showing the expected wait time in months that a person with a medium priority approval would wait if they joined the National Prioritisation System on 31 March 2019 is provided in Table C.

Aged Care
(Question No. 33)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians, in writing, on 3 July 2019:

In respect of a recent media article, 'Tied up for 12 hours: What happened to Terry could happen again under new rules' by Anne Connolly (ABC News, 27 June 2019): (a) why did the Department of Health not follow the directions of the then Minister for Senior Australians and Aged Care and prohibit the unreasonable use of chemical and physical restraint in the aged care sector; (b) were disciplinary proceedings commenced against any employees of the department as a consequence of the failure to follow the then Minister's direction; and (c) what steps will the Minister take to ensure the Department of Health, (i) prohibits the unreasonable use of chemical and physical restraints in the aged care sector, and (ii) is able to follow his directions with respect to policy reform.
Mr Hunt: The Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
Answer:
On 17 January 2019, the Australian Government announced that it would strengthen the regulations in relation to the use of physical and chemical restraint in aged care homes.

On 2 April 2019, the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians signed the regulations into law which, for the first time, put explicit obligations on residential aged care providers in respect of the use of restraint.
From 1 July 2019, residential aged care providers have specific responsibilities in relation to the use of physical and chemical restraint.

The responsibilties require providers to satisfy a number of conditions before restraint can be used, including assessment by an approved health practitioner (for physical restraint) or assessment by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who has prescribed the medication (for chemical restraint).
The provider must also ensure it uses the least restrictive form of restraint to address the risk of harm.

The aged care home must also have the informed consent of the consumer or their representative before using physical restraint, unless restraint is necessary in an emergency. The responsibility for seeking informed consent for prescription medications, including psychotropics, rests with the medical practitioner (rather than the residential aged care provider).
In all cases of restraint, the residential aged care provider is also required to document the alternative options of restraint that have been used.

A decision to use restraint should be a strategy of last resort and any use of restraint must also be regularly monitored. The restraint must be used for the minimum time necessary, and the need for the restraint must be reviewed.
Australian Border Force
(Question No. 34)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

(1) Is it a fact that relevant members of the Customs Marine Unit (CMU) have not been awarded the Australian Operational Service Medal - Border Protection for all declared operations, including but not only, Operation Relex I and II.(2) Are these members entitled to be awarded the medal?(3) Has there been a commitment by past or current governments to award the medal to all serving members of the CMU that participated in declared operations; if so, which minister and government made the commitment.(4) Will the Government award the medal to all eligible members of the CMU as a matter of priority; if not, why not.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
1) No. Australian Operational Service Medals (AOSM) – Border Protection, have been conferred to members of the Australian Border Force's (ABF's) Marine Unit.
2) ABF officers are not eligible to receive the current AOSM – Border Protection, due to the legislative instrument of employment that informs eligibility.

The Australian Operational Service Medal – Civilian, may be awarded to Defence civilians and other classes of civilians who are employed on Australian Defence Force (ADF) operations under the provisions of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982.
CMU members are employed under the Public Service Act 1999.
3) No.
4) Due to current eligibility regulations for this medal it will not be awarded to ABF Marine Unit officers.
Customs Marine Unit
(Question No. 35)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Veterans and Defence Personnel, in writing, on 3 July 2019:

(1)Is it a fact that relevant members of the Customs Marine Unit (CMU) have not been awarded the Australian Operational Service Medal - Border Protection for all declared operations, including but not only, Operation Relex I and II.
(2)Are these members entitled to be awarded the medal.

(3)Has there been a commitment by past or current governments to award the medal to all serving members of the CMU that participated in declared operations; if so, which minister and government made the commitment.
(4)Will the Government award the medal to all eligible members of the CMU as a matter of priority; if not, why not.
Mr Chester: The answer to the member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.

(2-4) No. The Australian Operational Service Medal - Border Protection is a Defence service award. It is only issued to eligible Defence Force members. This includes allied foreign Defence Force members serving with the Australian Defence Force. The regulations for this medal do not allow it to be awarded to a person who is not a Defence Force member.
Taxation
(Question No. 36)

Ms Sharkie To ask the Treasurer—(1) Is it a fact that prospective donors (individuals or families) who have established a Private Ancillary Fund (PAF) to manage their philanthropic giving, cannot do a direct distribution from their PAF to a community foundation with a Public Ancillary Fund (PuAF) structure because both PAFs and PuAFs have Deductible Gift Recipient (DGR) Item 2 status and cannot accept funds from another organisation with the same DGR status.(2) How does this restriction operate.(3) What is the policy rationale for this restriction.(4) Is this restriction a significant impediment to community foundations accessing donor funds.(5) For the 2017-2018 financial year: (a) how many community foundations were there in Australia with DGR status; (b) what quantity of funds did they have under management; and (c) what quantity of funds did they grant to their communities.(6) Has the Government considered: (a) creating an exemption for PAFs to make distributions to community foundations; if so, what was the conclusion of that consideration; if not, why not; and (b) awarding DGR Item 1 status to community foundations; if so, what was the conclusion of that consideration; if not, why not.(7) What plans does the Government have to enhance the effective operation of community foundations.
Mr Frydenberg: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.

(2) To be endorsed as a deductible gift recipient (DGR), an ancillary fund must be established for the sole purpose of providing money, property or benefit to a fund, authority or institution to which gifts are deductible under item 1 of the table at section 30‑15 of the Income Tax Assessment Act1997. As ancillary funds are covered by item 2 of that table, an ancillary fund cannot make distributions to another ancillary fund and retain its DGR status.

(3) The restriction is an integrity measure to ensure the full value of distributions from ancillary funds are provided to item 1 DGRs and in a reasonable time after the donor to the ancillary fund claims a tax deduction.
(4) Prospective donors may instead donate directly to a public ancillary fund established by a community foundation and claim a deduction in respect of that donation.

(5) As community foundation is not defined in tax law, specific statistics are not kept. However, (a) a complete list of deductible gift recipients, including public ancillary funds, is available from the Australian Business Register at www.abr.business.gov.au/Tools/DgrListing;

(b) the quantity of funds under management by public ancillary funds is available in the charities section of the Australian Taxation Office's taxation statistics at www.ato.gov.au/About-ATO/Research-and-statistics/In-detail/Taxation-statistics/; and (c) the quantity of funds distributed by public ancillary funds is available in the charities section of the taxation statistics.

(6) (a) and (b) During the 2017 consultation on deductible gift recipient reform, the Government received submissions advocating changes including permitting ancillary funds to make distributions to other ancillary funds and giving community foundations item 1 DGR status. On 5 December 2017, following this consultation, the then Minister for Revenue and Financial Services announced reforms to DGR administration to strengthen governance arrangements and reduce administrative complexity.

(7) Amendments to ancillary fund ministerial guidelines made in 2016 expanded the types of assistance ancillary funds may provide DGRs and reduced the reporting burdens on ancillary funds that are also registered charities.
Energy
(Question No. 37)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, in writing, on

(1) Has the Government undertaken cost-benefit analyses of community energy as a model to improve energy security and affordability; if so, what were the conclusions of those analyses; if not, why not.(2) In respect of the gap between some community energy groups achieving financial self-sufficiency in the longer-term, and the lack of public funding mechanisms available for them to securely establish themselves in the short- to mid-term, what funding streams or programs does the Government intend to implement to address this gap.(3) How does the Government intend to unlock the potential of community energy projects to address energy equity, reliability and affordability for all Australians.
Mr Taylor: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Government has provided funding to support community energy projects. This includes projects investigating community energy models, where distributed generation, storage and load are not co-located behind a single metered, connection point. Examples of projects supported by the Government include:
Curtin University developing governance models to allow shared solar PV, battery and monitoring systems to be used in medium density apartments
the Institute for Sustainable Futures investigating conditions required to support local electricity trading between customers and generators in the same distribution area

the development of analysis software to assess the value of different community energy models deployed throughout Australia to provide recommendations for new tariffs that incentivise community energy models

The Government is also delivering the Regional and Remote Communities Reliability Fund for communities to investigate whether establishing a microgrid is cost-effective. The fund will provide $50.4 support feasibility studies for microgrids in remote and regional areas.
If the Member has specific examples of projects she would like to draw to my attention, I encourage her to make contact.
Environment
(Question No. 38)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for the Environment, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

(1) How many square kilometres of native vegetation was cleared in Australia each year between 2015 and 2019, and what are the relevant public datasets for this information.(2) Where does Australia currently rank in the world for land clearance rates.(3) How many square kilometres of native vegetation are currently legally protected by Australian governments.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

1. The area of native forest clearing is reported each year as part of the National Greenhouse Accounts, where it is used to estimate greenhouse gas emissions on the land. The data is publicly available on the Australian Greenhouse Emissions Information System (http://ageis.climatechange.gov.au/QueryAppendixTable.aspx).
Year ending 30 June:
Primary forest conversion (Km2)
Re-clearing (Km2)
Total area of forest cleared (Km2)
The most recent data (published in April 2019) includes clearing up to the year 2017, due to time required for processing of satellite imagery.
2. The Department does not hold data that would enable it to answer this question.

3. Given the broad nature of the question, the Department does not hold a dataset which would enable it to answer this question fully, however information the Department has accessed through the Collaborative Australian Protected Areas Database identifies (CAPAD) 1,462,146 Km2 as protected. This calculation was done using the National Vegetation Information System 5.1. It should be noted that this does not include some offset land or private land and this dataset is taken as a point in time and does not provide for protection in perpetuity.
Environment
(Question No. 39)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for the Environment, in writing, on 3 July 2019:

(1) Which National Wilderness Inventories have been published for the various states and territories.(2) Why were the National Wilderness Inventories not published for all states and territories for which nationwide baseline wilderness quality assessment surveys were carried out; and will the Government publish these inventories.(3) Has the Government considered updating the National Wilderness Inventory; if so, what were its conclusions; if not, why not.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The National Wilderness Inventory was developed by the former Australian Heritage Commission in the 1980s and 1990s. It is no longer maintained by the Department of the Environment and Energy.

A brief description of the National Wilderness Inventory, published data and related work can be accessed at http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/gov/20080723182226/http://www.environment.gov.au/heritage/publications/anlr/index.html.
A summary of the production and use of the National Wilderness Inventory can be accessed at https://www.environment.gov.au/node/20141.
(2) The Government does not intend to publish any of the National Wilderness Inventory and related work beyond what is already accessible via the National Library archive website.
(3) The Government has not considered updating the Inventory, given the time that has elapsed since the program was ceased.
Environment
(Question No. 40)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for the Environment, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

(1 ) Has the Government been formally informed by the Ramsar Convention Secretariat of any Article 3.2 request for Montreux Record listing of the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Ramsar Wetland in South Australia; if so: (a) on what date; and (b) what was the Government's response.(2) Has the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Ramsar Wetland site deteriorated in the past five years; if so, can the Minister detail that deterioration.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) (a) Yes. On 15 February 2019, the Secretary General of the Ramsar Convention forwarded a letter from Rebekha Sharkie MP (and others) requesting a notification of change in ecological character (under Article 3.2 of the Ramsar Convention) for the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Ramsar site, and the site's listing on the Montreux Record.

(b) The Australian Ramsar Administrative Authority responded to the Ramsar Secretary General on 30 April 2019, advising that as the site already has an open Article 3.2 notification, a further notification is not required.

The response noted that the site should not been listed on the Montreux Record, on the basis that Australia has committed significant scientific and financial resources towards the recovery of the site and that Montreux listing is not appropriate while the Australian and South Australian governments continue to work towards the recovery of the site.

In 2006, the Australian Government notified the Ramsar Convention Secretariat of a change in the ecological character of the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Wetland Ramsar site in accordance with Article 3.2 of the Convention. The notification was based on the 2006 ecological character description, which reported the site was in decline for 20 to 30 years prior to designation (in 1985), and that further decline was inevitable. The Millennium Drought (from 1996 to 2010) further impacted the ecological character of the site. At the time of the Article 3.2 notification, the site still met the eight Ramsar criteria for which it was designated.

(2) No. The condition of the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Ramsar Wetland has improved since the Millennium Drought broke in 2010, as a result of inflows from the Murray-Darling Basin, the provision of Commonwealth Environmental Water and through recovery actions funded and implemented through the Coorong, Lower Lakes and Murray Mouth Recovery Project.

Despite dry conditions, water for the environment has supported a continuous connection between the Lower Lakes and the Coorong for over three years, providing favourable estuarine habitat and maintaining salinity levels in the Coorong lagoons below maximum thresholds. The first successful large-scale recruitment of black bream in the Coorong since the Millennium Drought occurred in 2017-18, and this strong cohort continues to persist. Multiple consecutive years of good recruitment of diadromous fish species such as congolli and common galaxias have seen populations strongly rebuild, while both pouched and short-headed lamprey have been recorded migrating through the site after complete absence from 2007-2010.

Vegetation communities in Lake Alexandrina are also becoming more diverse and key species more abundant, providing habitat for small-bodied threatened fish species including southern pygmy perch and Murray hardyhead. While full recovery from the impacts of prolonged drought will take many years, these findings indicate gradually improving condition for many ecological aspects of the site.
(See also response to House of Representatives Question No. 41).
Environment
(Question No. 41)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for the Environment, in writing, on 03 July 2019:
What steps is the Government taking to improve the ecological condition of the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Ramsar Wetland site in South Australia.
Ms Ley: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The condition of the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Wetland has improved since the Millennium Drought broke in 2010, as a result of inflows from the Murray-Darling Basin, provision of Commonwealth Environmental Water and recovery actions implemented through the Coorong, Lower Lakes and Murray Mouth Recovery Project.

During the peak of the Millennium Drought (1996 -2010), the Australian Government provided $46.5 million to fund bioremediation and emergency measures, including the installation of two temporary regulators and a bund to critical parts of the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Wetland. These were removed when flows to the site increased in 2010. This funding package included a feasibility study, which resulted in the publication of: Securing the future: A long-term plan for the Coorong, Lower Lakes and Murray Mouth (Long Term Plan). This publication set out a 20 year plan for the future management of the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Wetland Ramsar site.

Since 2012, the Australian Government has invested approximately $123 million into the Coorong, Lower Lakes and Murray Mouth Recovery Project. This was funded from commitments in the 2008 Intergovernmental Agreement on Murray-Darling Basin Reform, and is administered by the Department of Agriculture. This project supports implementation of the Long Term Plan and works to restore biodiversity; improve our knowledge base of the system; and encourage indigenous and broader community involvement in the management of the site.

The Recovery Project includes the development of a revised Ecological Character Description (ECD) to describe the condition of the site in 2015. The ECD shows that the ecological character of the site is recovering following the impacts of the Millennium Drought. Due to the current management arrangements, many of the critical values are returning to within their range of natural variability.

A range of ecological outcomes in the Coorong and Lakes Alexandrina and Albert Wetland have been reported from monitoring in recent years. Despite dry conditions, water for the environment has supported a continuous connection between the Lower Lakes and the Coorong for over three years, providing favourable estuarine habitat and maintaining salinity levels in the Coorong lagoons below maximum thresholds.

The first successful large-scale recruitment of black bream in the Coorong since the Millennium Drought occurred in 2017-18, and this strong cohort of fish, now more than a year old, continues to persist. Multiple consecutive years of good recruitment of diadromous fish species such as congolli and common galaxias have seen populations strongly rebuild, while both pouched and short-headed lamprey have been recorded migrating through the site after complete absence from 2007-2010. Vegetation communities in Lake Alexandrina are also becoming more diverse and key species more abundant, providing habitat for small-bodied threatened fish species including southern pygmy perch and Murray hardyhead. While full recovery from the impacts of prolonged drought will take many years, these findings indicate gradually improving condition for many ecological aspects of the site.

The Australian and South Australian governments are providing further additional funding of up to $77 million to extend efforts to improve conditions at the Coorong South Lagoon (part of the Ramsar site) through joint funding of the new Healthy Coorong, Healthy Basin Program. Some early program activities are already underway. The South Australian Government has provided a business case for the first phase of works, for up to $25 million of the $70 million Australian Government commitment. The Department of Agriculture is currently undertaking a due diligence assessment of this proposal.
(See also response to House of Representatives Question No. 40).
