p.span: Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority
(Question No. 45)
Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, in writing, on 03 July 2019:

1. In respect of the educational visit by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) to suppliers of agricultural chemicals and veterinary medicines in Tamworth and Coffs Harbour on 29 and 30 May 2019: (a) who are the suppliers of agricultural chemicals and veterinary medicines that the APVMA visited; and (b) who from the APVMA attended the visits.

2. How many other educational visits has the APVMA undertaken in 2018-19, and: (a) who organised the visits; (b) what was the cost to the APVMA for the visits; and (c) who paid for APVMA staff to attend the educational visits.
3. What advice did the APVMA provide the suppliers about new labelling requirements for 2,4-D.
4. Why was it necessary for the APVMA to highlight to the suppliers how adverse experiences can be reported to the APVMA.
5. How did the suppliers demonstrate their appreciation to the APVMA for the time it spent discussing these issues.
Mr Littleproud: The Minister for Agriculture has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
1. a). The four suppliers were: Tamworth Rural; Elders Rural, Tamworth; Norco Rural, Coffs Harbour; North Coast Chemicals, Coffs Harbour.
b). Two staff from the Compliance and Monitoring Team.
2. These visits were a new element of the APVMA's Compliance and Monitoring Team activities and were the only ones of this kind to occur in FY 18-19
a) The APVMA Compliance and Monitoring Team organised the visits.
b) Approximately $175.
c) APVMA
3. a) APVMA staff provided advice about the labelling requirements consistent with advice published on the APVMA website (www.apvma.gov.au/node/32941).
4. a). Increasing awareness of the Adverse Experience Reporting Program (AERP) is part of the APVMA's 2018-19 Annual Compliance Plan.
5. a) The suppliers verbally thanked the APVMA personnel for the information provided.
Safer Communities Fund
(Question No. 46)
Mr Gorman asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in writing, on 4 July 2019:

In respect of the Safer Communities Fund Round 4:(1) As Opportunity 1 for applications closed on 4 April 2019: (a) when will there be a further round of applications; and (b) how long will the opportunity for applications remain open.(2) How many applications are currently being considered; and of these, how many are from Western Australia.(3) What further information can be provided for potential applicants in the electoral division of Perth.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

(1) While program guidelines for round four of the Safer Communities Fund allowed for the round to open again if funding was available, the round was heavily oversubscribed so it is unlikely that it will open again for further applications.

(2) The Department of Home Affairs received 690 applications under the round and they are currently being assessed by the Department of Industry, Innovation and Science. Out of the 690 applications 102 of these applications are from Western Australia.

(3) Decisions on round four of the Safer Communities Fund are expected to be made in the coming months. During the 2019 election campaign the Government committed an additional $20 million towards round five of the Safer Communities Fund, on top of the $35.1 million announced in the 2019-20 Budget. Arrangements for this round are currently being established. Once arrangements are in place, further information about the grant opportunity will be published on the Australian Government's Grant Connect website at www.grants.gov.au.

(Question No. 71)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians, in writing, on 22 July 2019:

(1) Is it a fact that the waiting list for home care packages for older Australians across Australia has grown from 88,000 in June 2017 to more than 129,000 as at 31 March 2019. (2) What number of the approximately 129,000 people waiting to receive their approved level of home care package reside in the electoral division of Mayo, and of these, how many: (a) have been approved for Level 1, 2, 3 and 4 packages; and (b) are on an interim home care package and awaiting their approved package level. (3) What is the average wait time for the receipt of approved levels of home care package applications in: (a) Australia; (b) South Australia; and (c) the electoral division of Mayo.
Mr Hunt: The Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Yes
(2) The Department of Health (the Department) does not collect this information at an electoral division level.

(3) The Department does not break down data on elapsed wait times beyond the national level. Infrastructure
(Question No. 91)
Mr Georganas asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, in writing, on 29 July 2019:

1) Can the Minister assure the people of Adelaide that works associated with the north-south corridor expansion of the South Road upgrade will preserve the heritage listed historic buildings of Thebarton Theatre and Queen of Angels Church.
2) What processes have been put in place to ensure the iconic heritage listed Thebarton Theatre and Queens of Angels Church will be preserved.
Mr McCormack: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
A Business Case is under development and the project design and alignment is yet to be settled.

Once the preferred design option has been identified and concept plans developed, the Australian and South Australian Governments will have greater certainty of impacts on the community including potential land requirements and timing. Where land acquisition is required, every effort will be made to minimise impacts on schools and services as well as sites of social, heritage and environmental significance such as the Thebarton Theatre and the Queen of Angels Church.

Maldon to Dombarton Rail Link Feasibility Study

Drawing on the outcomes of the Pre-Feasibility Study, this study conducted a detailed analysis of existing structures, engineering requirements, demand for usage of the line, economic and financial modelling and land use and environmental planning issues.
Maldon - Dombarton Rail Link - Scoping and Development
The project undertook pre construction activities including:
preparation of detailed design work for civil, structural, geotechnical and track work necessary for the future construction of the project; and
BULLET finalisation of a construction timetable and cost estimate for the project.
Ballast Rehabilitation Program
The project upgraded ballast on the rail line between Sydney and Melbourne.
Sydney to Wollongong Fast Rail Business Case
The project will develop a business case to investigate options for faster passenger rail services from Sydney to Wollongong.

Centrelink
(Question No. 98)
Ms Sharkie To the Minister for Government Services –

(1) How many complaints has the Department of Human Services received from or on behalf of Centrelink customers regarding the department's Centrepay policy and terms during: (a) 2016; (b) 2017; (c) 2018; and (d) 1 January 2019 to 30 June 2019.
(2) Of the complaints referred to in (1), how many were referred to other regulatory or law enforcement bodies.
(3) How many assurance checks did the department undertake on businesses using Centrepay during: (a) 2016; (b) 2017; (c) 2018; and (d) 1 January 2019 to 30 June 2019.

(4) In conducting the assurance checks noted in (3): (a) on how many occasions did the department suspend approval or place temporary conditions on the business' use of Centrepay; and (b) on how many occasions did the assurance check result in the withdrawal of approval for the business to use Centrepay.
(5) What is the average wait time in days for the department to respond to Centrelink customers' complaints regarding the conduct of a business which has departmental approval to use Centrepay.
Mr Robert: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) How many complaints has the Department of Human Services received from or on behalf of Centrelink customers regarding the department's Centrepay policy and terms during:
(d) 1 January 2019 to 30 June 2019.
During the period specified, the following complaints have been received.
Complaint Category
Total
*The increase in complaints in 2019 can be largely attributed to adjustments to processes with the removal of the Centrepay the easy way to pay your bills (SA325) form, and
an increase in complaints of a regulatory nature from advocacy groups that were subsequently referred to regulatory bodies.
(2) Of the complaints referred to in (1), how many were referred to other regulatory or law enforcement bodies.
Nine complaints were referred to regulatory bodies.
(3) How many assurance checks did the department undertake on businesses using
Centrepay during:
(d) 1 January 2019 to 30 June 2019.
Assurance Checks*
Random Assurance Checks
Targeted Assurance Checks
Total
*Assurance data are collected on a financial year basis, not by calendar year.
**The reduction in the number of reviews is due to a refinement in assurance selection processes.
(4) In conducting the assurance checks noted in (3):
(a) on how many occasions did the department suspend approval or place temporary conditions on the business' use of Centrepay; and
(b) on how many occasions did the assurance check result in the withdrawal of approval for the business to use Centrepay.

Data in the table below relates to all businesses suspended or withdrawn from Centrepay and is not limited to the group listed at (3). We do not apply temporary conditions on the use of Centrepay, noting permanent conditions may be added to a business' terms and conditions.
Suspensions
Withdrawals*
* Businesses may have their Centrepay approval withdrawn by the Department including where the business:
is inactive for 12 months;
changes in business structure (e.g. sale of business);
consolidates (e.g. franchises); or
is non-compliant
** These numbers are due to contract transition and integrity process updates that saw a high number of inactive businesses withdrawn.
(5) What is the average wait time in days for the department to respond to Centrelink
customers' complaints regarding the conduct of a business which has departmental approval to use Centrepay.

The Department attempts to contact the customer and resolve where possible within 10 business days of a complaint being lodged. However, depending on the complexity of the complaint and the customer's circumstances, it can take longer to contact and resolve.
Taxation
(Question No. 101)

Ms Sharkie asked the Minister for Education 31 July 2019 -1. In respect of subparagraph 200B(1) (b) (iii) of A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Act 1999 , for families who only utilise Outside School Hours Care (OSHC) during holiday periods ('Vacation Care') more than eight weeks apart, has the Government considered extending the time period for enrolments to lapse; if so, what was the conclusion; if not, why not.2. Does the Government consider that an extension to twelve weeks would significantly reduce the administrative burden on Government, parents and OSHC providers; if not, why not.
Mr Tehan: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Australian Government acknowledges that while this provision is designed to improve transparency of Government fee assistance and child care arrangements to all families, a number of circumstances have been raised by child care providers and families where children only attend child care during school holidays.
The Government is open to receiving and considering feedback.

1(b) No.

The NPS ensures that people are eligible to be assigned a lower level home care package at an earlier stage. The aged care system also allows for those in urgent need for a home care package, to be assessed as high priority and for them to be assigned a package or access other supports quickly.
